Identify the animal if possible (domestic vs. wild, vaccinated vs. unvaccinated). Wild animal bites (especially bats, raccoons, skunks, foxes) carry a high rabies risk. Monitor for signs of infection (redness, pus, fever, increasing pain) and seek medical help for rabies prophylaxis if available.

examples: Example: Puncture Wounds - Do not try to close deep puncture wounds; they need to drain. Clean very thoroughly inside and out.
Example: Rabies Suspect - If bitten by a potentially rabid animal, consider all possible means to reach medical help, as rabies is almost always fatal once symptoms appear.
dos: Clean the wound immediately and thoroughly.
Observe the animal if safe to do so (for rabies assessment).
Seek medical attention for all animal bites, especially deep ones.
donts: Don't ignore any animal bite, even a small scratch.
Don't try to catch or corner an agitated or wild animal.
Don't apply superglue or tape to a bite wound that might be infected or needs to drain.

survivalGuides.title: Starting Fire with a Fire Bow
survivalGuides.description: The steps for constructing and effectively using a fire bow to create friction heat, resulting in a hot coal (ember) to ignite tinder.
quickSteps: 1. Gather four components: Bow, Spindle, Hearth Board, and Handhold.
2. Prepare the tinder nest and notch in the hearth board.
3. Drill the spindle rapidly until smoke appears.
4. Transfer the resulting coal to the tinder nest and blow gently.

fullSteps.detail: Choose non-resinous, medium-soft, dry wood (e.g., cedar, willow, aspen) for the spindle and hearth board. The bowstring can be paracord, leather, or sturdy plant fiber.
Carve a small depression in the hearth board. Cut a small V-shaped notch leading from the depression to the edge; this is where the coal will drop.
Wrap the bowstring once around the spindle. Hold the handhold firmly over the top of the spindle. Move the bow back and forth in long, smooth, quick strokes, applying downward pressure.
Once a smoking black powder forms in the notch, stop. Carefully tap the board to drop the glowing coal onto the prepared tinder nest. Blow gently and consistently until the tinder ignites.

examples: Example: Handhold - Use a concave stone, shell, or piece of wood with oil/fat applied inside to reduce friction against the spindle.
Example: Tinder Nest - Use fine, dry materials like birch bark shavings, dried grass, or shredded cedar bark.
dos: Use long, smooth strokes with the bow.
Keep the spindle perpendicular to the hearth board.
Maintain constant downward pressure on the handhold.
donts: Don't use green, wet, or resinous wood.
Don't stop bowing too soon after smoke appears.
Don't let the coal cool before transferring it to the tinder.

survivalGuides.title: Edible Insects and Foraging Safety
survivalGuides.description: Safe guidelines for foraging insects (entomophagy), which are abundant sources of protein and fat, and what types to strictly avoid.
quickSteps: 1. Never eat brightly colored insects.
2. Avoid hairy, stinging, or biting insects.
3. Remove wings, legs, and heads before eating.
4. Always cook insects thoroughly to kill parasites.

fullSteps.detail: Common edible insects include grasshoppers, crickets, ants and ant larvae (eggs), termites, and some beetles (remove hard outer shells).
Avoid bright red, yellow, or blue insects (sign of poison). Avoid large hairy spiders/caterpillars, wasps, bees, and insects that bite or sting. Never eat adult butterflies or moths.
Kill the insects quickly. Remove any hard, sharp, or inedible parts (wings, legs, antennae, heads). Fasting the insects for a day can help clear their digestive tracts.
Always cook insects by roasting, boiling, or frying them to destroy any parasites or bacteria. Cook until they are crispy and thoroughly dry.

examples: Example: Crickets - Roast them over a fire until crunchy. They are high in protein.
Example: Larvae - Grubs (beetle larvae) found inside rotting logs are often safe, high-fat sources.
dos: Eat insects found in clean, non-polluted areas.
Focus on soft-bodied insects like grubs and larvae.
Start by eating small quantities.
donts: Don't eat brightly patterned or strong-smelling insects.
Don't eat insects raw (risk of parasites).
Don't consume caterpillars or tarantulas (unless you are a local expert).

survivalGuides.title: Improvising Snow Goggles
survivalGuides.description: How to create emergency eye protection to prevent snow blindness (corneal burn from UV reflection) when stranded in snowy or highly reflective environments.
quickSteps: 1. Find a piece of rigid, non-reflective material (bark, plastic).
2. Cut the material to fit over your eyes like a mask.
3. Carve a thin horizontal slit (pinhole) at eye level.
4. Secure the goggles around your head.

fullSteps.detail: Use a piece of smooth, non-reflective wood, tree bark, cardboard, or heavy plastic debris. The material must be large enough to completely shield the eyes from peripheral light.
Cut or carve a very narrow, horizontal slit (about 1/16 to 1/8 inch wide) directly in front of each eye. The slit must be narrow enough to reduce the amount of light entering the eye.
The inner surface of the mask facing your eyes should be painted black or darkened with soot from a fire to absorb stray light and prevent reflection.
Use thin strips of cloth, cordage, or elastic bands (if available) to secure the goggles tightly around the head, ensuring they are positioned correctly and comfortable enough for long-term wear.

examples: Example: Treatment - If snow blindness occurs, bandage the eyes shut and rest in a dark place. The condition is temporary but painful.
Example: Alternative - Use a piece of cloth with two small holes poked through it, tied around the face like a mask.
dos: Make the goggles fit tightly to block side light.
Darken the interior surface of the goggles.
Use them immediately upon entering a highly reflective area.
donts: Don't use reflective material (like foil or shiny plastic).
Don't make the slits too wide.
Don't rub your eyes if snow blindness symptoms begin.

survivalGuides.title: Using the Hand Method for Direction
survivalGuides.image: [Image showing a hand held up to the sun to tell time]
survivalGuides.description: An improvised method of determining direction and approximate time using only the sun and your outstretched hand, applicable in both hemispheres.
quickSteps: 1. Find the local solar noon (when the sun is highest).
2. At solar noon, the sun is due South (Northern Hemisphere).
3. For every 15 degrees the sun moves from South, one hour has passed.
4. Alternatively, use a shadow stick for a more precise direction.

fullSteps.detail: Use the shadow stick method: place a stick upright, mark the tip of the shadow. Wait 10-15 minutes, mark the new tip. A line perpendicular to the shortest shadow of the day indicates North-South.

Hold your hand out fully, palm flat, thumb facing up. Each finger width (held at arm's length) represents approximately 15 minutes of sun travel. Stacking your hands, each hand width equals roughly 1 hour.
Once the North-South line is established (via shadow stick), you can deduce East and West. Remember: the sun rises roughly in the East and sets roughly in the West.
In the Southern Hemisphere, the sun is always due North at local solar noon.

examples: Example: Shadow Stick - Place the stick's base on the first mark, and the second mark becomes the direction of travel for the next 15 minutes.
Example: Time Estimation - If the sun is four hand widths above the western horizon, it's approximately 4 hours until sunset.
dos: Use the shortest shadow to determine the most accurate North/South line.
Adjust your location to ensure an unblocked view of the sun.
Use this method only during daylight hours.
donts: Don't rely on the sun's position at the horizon for direction (it varies too much).
Don't forget that magnetic North and true North are different.
Don't stare directly at the sun.

survivalGuides.title: Safe Consumption of Wild Edible Greens
survivalGuides.description: Guidelines for safely harvesting common wild greens (like dandelion, clover, cattail) and preparation methods to maximize nutrition and minimize gastric distress.
quickSteps: 1. Identify the plant with 100% certainty.
2. Avoid plants near roads or polluted water.
3. Boil all unknown or potentially irritating greens.
4. Eat only a small test amount first.

fullSteps.detail: Focus on known edibles like Dandelion (leaves, roots, flowers), Clover (leaves and flowers), Chicory, and Cattail (roots, shoots). Never trust a general plant identification rule.

If necessary, perform the Universal Edibility Test: rub plant on skin, wait 15 min; rub on lips, wait 15 min; touch to tongue, wait 15 min; chew a small amount, wait 5 hours. If no reaction, consume a larger amount.
Many wild greens (e.g., pokeweed, fiddleheads) must be boiled in multiple changes of water to remove toxins or reduce bitterness. Cooking also kills some parasites.
Eat a small portion first. Too many wild greens too quickly can cause diarrhea or severe gastric distress, especially if your body is not used to the high fiber content.

examples: Example: Cattail - The root stalk (rhizome) can be peeled and boiled or roasted like a potato; the green shoots can be eaten raw.
Example: Dandelion - The entire plant is edible, but the older leaves are bitter and best boiled.
dos: Wash all plants thoroughly with purified water.
Harvest only what you need and leave the rest to grow.
Focus on tender, new shoots and leaves.
donts: Don't eat mushrooms unless you are an expert.
Don't eat leaves that are shiny or grow in clusters of three.
Don't eat plants that taste excessively bitter or soapy.

survivalGuides.title: Treating Severe Burns (2nd and 3rd Degree)
survivalGuides.description: Immediate first aid for serious burns (those with blisters, white or charred skin). Focus on reducing heat, preventing infection, and managing shock.
quickSteps: 1. Stop the burning process (remove clothes, cool skin).
2. Cool the burn area with cool (not freezing) water.
3. Cover the burn with a sterile, non-fluffy dressing.
4. Treat for shock and seek medical help immediately.

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Stop the Burn and Cool
fullSteps.detail: Smother flames. Remove clothing *unless* it is stuck to the skin. Immediately cool the burn with cool (not ice-cold) running water for 10-20 minutes. Do not use ice.
Cover the burn with a dry, sterile, non-adhesive dressing or clean, non-fluffy cloth. Avoid breaking blisters. Do not apply butter, oil, or any home remedies.
Lay the victim flat, elevate the legs (if no spinal injury), and cover them with a blanket to prevent hypothermia, which is common with severe burns.
Treat burns to the face, eyes, hands, feet, or genitals, or burns covering a large area (larger than the palm of the hand) as extreme emergencies.

examples: Example: Chemical Burns - Flush with running water for 30 minutes or more. If dry chemical (e.g., powder), brush it off first before flushing.
Example: Electrical Burns - Ensure the power source is off before touching the victim. Electrical burns often have a hidden internal component.
dos: Cool the burn for at least 10 minutes.
Remove constricting jewelry/clothing before swelling starts.
Keep the victim calm and monitor breathing.
donts: Don't use ice or freezing water.
Don't break blisters.
Don't use adhesive dressings directly on the burn.

survivalGuides.title: Surviving Earthquakes and Aftershocks
survivalGuides.description: Immediate actions during an earthquake to protect yourself from falling debris, and post-quake safety procedures for checking infrastructure and managing aftershocks.
quickSteps: 1. Drop to the ground immediately.
2. Cover your head and neck under sturdy furniture.
3. Hold on until the shaking stops.
4. Post-quake, check for injuries and shut off utilities (gas/water/electric).

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Drop, Cover, and Hold On (Indoors)
fullSteps.detail: Drop to your hands and knees. Take cover under a strong piece of furniture (table, desk). Hold on to the furniture and be prepared to move with it.
If outdoors, move away from buildings, streetlights, and utility wires. Drop to the ground. If driving, pull over to a clear area, set the parking brake, and stay inside.
Wait until the shaking stops. Check yourself and others for injuries. Put on sturdy shoes and check for structural damage and fire hazards.
If you smell gas, shut off the main gas line (using the proper wrench). Avoid using elevators. Prepare for strong aftershocks by moving to a safe, pre-designated area.

examples: Example: Tsunami Threat - If near the coast and the shaking is severe, move to high ground immediately, as a tsunami may follow.
Example: Apartment - Move to an interior wall or under a heavy door frame (if necessary), away from glass.
dos: Have an emergency kit and supplies ready.
Anticipate and prepare for aftershocks.
Use battery-powered lighting (not matches or candles).
donts: Don't run out of a building during the shaking.
Don't use fire/flames until you are sure there are no gas leaks.
Don't re-enter a visibly damaged building.

survivalGuides.title: Hunting with Improvised Weapons (Spear)
survivalGuides.description: Instructions for creating a basic hunting spear from natural materials, focusing on sharpening and fire-hardening the tip for effectiveness against small to medium game.
quickSteps: 1. Select a straight, strong shaft (6-8 feet long).
2. Carve a long, sharp point at one end.
3. Fire-harden the tip over a low fire.
4. Practice silent throwing and thrusting.

fullSteps.detail: Find a stick that is as straight and dry as possible, about 6 to 8 feet long and thick enough to handle. Bamboo, ash, or maple are good choices.
Use a knife or sharp stone to carve a long, fine point (about 6-8 inches long) on one end. The point should be symmetric and smoothly tapered.

Hold the carved tip over the **coals** (not flames) of a small fire. Rotate the tip slowly until the wood changes color to dark brown or black. This process removes moisture and makes the wood harder and more durable.
Spears are most effective for thrusting at prey trapped in snares or near water. For throwing, focus on small game at close range. Always aim for a vital area (head, chest).

examples: Example: Multi-Pronged Spear - For fishing, split the tip of the spear into 3 or 4 prongs and secure them to make a trident-style spear (gig).
Example: Stabilization - Use thin cordage wrapped around the base of the point to prevent the tip from splitting during impact.
dos: Carve the point smoothly and symmetrically.
Focus on thrusting rather than throwing for larger game.
Practice silently stalking and aiming.
donts: Don't use rotten or overly brittle wood.
Don't hold the tip directly in flames (it will burn, not harden).
Don't waste energy on large prey until you are skilled and have backup.

survivalGuides.title: Managing Altitude Sickness (AMS)
survivalGuides.description: Recognition and treatment of Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS) and the critical, life-threatening forms (HACE and HAPE) when trekking at high elevations.
quickSteps: 1. Go no higher (for mild AMS).
2. Descend immediately if symptoms worsen or confusion occurs.
3. Drink plenty of water and rest.
4. Avoid alcohol and heavy exertion.

fullSteps.detail: Symptoms are similar to a hangover: headache, nausea, loss of appetite, dizziness, and fatigue, usually occurring above 8,000 feet.

High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE): Confusion, lack of coordination. High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE): Extreme fatigue, wet cough, shortness of breath at rest. **Immediate descent is mandatory.**
Stop ascending, rest, and hydrate. Use pain relievers for headache. Do not go higher until symptoms resolve. Acclimatization is key.
Descend as quickly and safely as possible (at least 2,000 feet). Descent is the only definitive cure. Administer oxygen if available.

examples: Example: Prevention - Ascend slowly (no more than 1,000 feet of elevation gain per day above 8,000 feet).
Example: Hydration - Urine should be clear or light yellow; dark urine is a sign of dehydration.
dos: Hydrate constantly.
Descend immediately if HACE/HAPE is suspected.
Listen to your body and rest when needed.
donts: Don't use sleeping pills or alcohol (depress breathing).
Don't ignore the early signs of AMS.
Don't ascend quickly past the recommended altitude gain.

survivalGuides.title: Making and Using Char Cloth
survivalGuides.description: How to make highly effective char cloth from cotton fabric, which easily catches a spark from flint and steel (or a ferro rod) and smolders to ignite a tinder nest.
quickSteps: 1. Cut 100% cotton cloth into small squares.
2. Place the squares into a metal container (Altoid tin).
3. Puncture a small hole in the lid (vent hole).
4. Heat the tin in a fire until white smoke stops, then let it cool.

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Preparing the Tin and Cloth
fullSteps.detail: Use a metal container (like a mint tin) and ensure the lid closes tightly. Cut a small hole (pinhole size) in the lid. Fill the tin with pieces of 100% cotton (jeans, t-shirts, canvas). Do not use synthetics.
Place the tin directly into the hot coals of a fire. You will see white smoke puffing from the vent hole. This smoke is flammable gas being released.
When the smoke stops venting (about 5-15 minutes), use a stick to pull the tin out of the fire. Plug the hole with a stick or rock and let the tin cool completely. Do not open while hot.

Open the tin and remove a piece of black char cloth. Place it near the tinder nest. Strike a spark onto the cloth. It will catch the spark and begin to glow red. Transfer the glowing cloth to the tinder nest and blow gently.

examples: Example: Raw Material - Old cotton t-shirts, denim, and cotton bandanas work best. Avoid blended fabrics.
Example: Result - If the cloth is brown or crispy, it needs more heat. If it is gray ash, it was overcooked.
dos: Use 100% natural fiber material.
Ensure the tin is sealed tightly.
Let the tin cool completely before opening.
donts: Don't use plastic containers or synthetic fabric.
Don't let air into the tin while it is hot (it will catch fire and turn to ash).
Don't overfill the tin.

survivalGuides.title: Surviving in a Hot Desert Environment
survivalGuides.description: Essential strategies for avoiding heat stroke, finding and conserving limited water resources, and traveling efficiently in arid, high-temperature climates.
quickSteps: 1. Prioritize shade and rest during daylight hours.
2. Travel only at night or during the cooler parts of the day.
3. Cover all skin and the head to prevent water loss.
4. Ration sweat, not water (drink when you are thirsty).

fullSteps.detail: Build or find shelter immediately. The best shelters are those that offer shade and allow air to flow through. Minimize all physical activity during the hottest part of the day (10 AM to 4 PM).
Wear light-colored, loose-fitting clothing to cover all skin, trapping a thin layer of air that cools sweat before it evaporates, reducing water loss. This is called 'oversweating prevention.'
Look for green vegetation, low points where water may collect underground, or follow animal/bird tracks (especially early morning). Use solar stills to collect condensation.
If you must move, travel at night, using the stars or moon for navigation. Rest and monitor your water supply during the day.

examples: Example: Rationing - Drink enough water to keep urine light yellow. Strict water rationing can lead to mental impairment and poor decisions.
Example: Shelter - Dig a shallow trench on the shady side of a dune or large rock and cover it with a poncho or blanket.
dos: Cover all exposed skin (face, neck, hands).
Stay mentally calm to conserve energy.
Plan your movements meticulously before setting out.
donts: Don't drink urine or seawater.
Don't remove clothing in the daytime heat.
Don't exert yourself during the hottest hours.

survivalGuides.title: Treating Diarrhea and Dehydration
survivalGuides.description: The critical importance of fluid and electrolyte replacement during severe diarrhea (a common symptom of waterborne illness) to prevent life-threatening dehydration.
quickSteps: 1. Stop the cause (don't eat bad food/water).
2. Sip small, frequent amounts of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).
3. Do not take antidiarrheal medications unless absolutely necessary (can trap pathogens).
4. Monitor urine output and color (should be pale yellow).

fullSteps.detail: Mix 1 quart of purified water with 6 teaspoons of sugar and $1/2$ teaspoon of salt (or equivalent ratio). This balances salts and glucose for optimal absorption.
Drink small, frequent sips of the ORS. Drinking too much too fast can induce vomiting. Continue drinking even if the diarrhea is persistent.
Do not eat heavy, greasy, or spicy foods. Focus on simple starches (rice, boiled grains) and rest. Severe diarrhea depletes energy and requires total rest.
Symptoms include sunken eyes, lack of urination, lethargy, no tears, or very dry mouth. If these occur, the victim needs urgent medical attention.

examples: Example: Alternative Electrolytes - Use clear broth, mashed bananas (if available), or diluted sports drinks if ORS ingredients are missing.
Example: Stomach Cramps - A small amount of activated charcoal (if available) may help absorb toxins.
dos: Drink purified water only.
Maintain strict hand and food hygiene.
Prioritize fluid intake over food intake.
donts: Don't drink plain water (flushes out electrolytes).
Don't drink fruit juices (high sugar makes diarrhea worse).
Don't drink alcohol or coffee.

survivalGuides.title: Surviving Coastal/Ocean Situations
survivalGuides.description: Essential strategies for surviving shipwreck, focusing on immediate action, flotation, signaling, and protection against hypothermia and dehydration.
quickSteps: 1. Put on a life vest/PFD immediately (if available).
2. Grab the nearest flotation device/Go-Bag.
3. Stay with the boat/wreckage as long as possible (better visibility).
4. Conserve heat (H.E.L.P. position).

fullSteps.detail: Do not enter the water until necessary. If you must, wear as many layers of clothing as possible (protection from cold and sun). Keep a piece of wreckage for buoyancy.
If alone, pull knees to chest and hug them (Heat Escape Lessening Posture). If with others, huddle tightly together in a circle, facing inwards, to share and conserve core body heat.
Use a signal mirror, dye marker (if available), or a whistle (three blasts). Use bright objects (plastic, fabric) floating high on the water to increase visibility to aircraft.
Do not drink seawater. Distill water or collect rainwater. Fish for food only when necessary and conserve energy. Fish eyes are a good source of moisture.

examples: Example: Shark Threat - Remain as still as possible and avoid unnecessary splashing. If attacked, fight back aggressively.
Example: Direction - Use the sun and stars (ID 113) for navigation toward the nearest landmass; sometimes floating with the current is safest.
dos: Stay together if in a group.
Conserve energy and minimize unnecessary movement.
Wear your PFD at all times.
donts: Don't drink seawater (it speeds up dehydration).
Don't inflate your PFD until you are clear of the sinking vessel.
Don't remove clothing unless you are overheating.

survivalGuides.title: Surviving a Lightning Storm
survivalGuides.description: Critical procedures for finding safe shelter during a lightning storm and immediate first aid for a lightning strike victim.
quickSteps: 1. Seek immediate shelter in a large, sturdy building or a hard-topped vehicle.
2. Avoid contact with plumbing, wires, and electronics.
3. If outdoors and exposed, adopt the 'Lightning Crouch.'
4. Treat strike victims for burns and cardiac arrest (start CPR).

fullSteps.detail: If you hear thunder, lightning is close enough to strike. Get inside a substantial building or a metal-topped car. Do not shelter in small sheds, tents, or under isolated trees.
Stay away from windows, doors, and anything that conducts electricity (plumbing, landline phones, wiring). Do not bathe or wash dishes during a storm.
If trapped outside, find a low spot away from tall objects. Crouch low to the ground on the balls of your feet, placing your hands over your ears. Minimize contact with the ground.
Lightning strike victims do not hold a charge and are safe to touch. Check breathing and pulse immediately. If absent, start CPR (lightning often causes cardiac arrest).

examples: Example: Golf Course/Open Field - Drop all metal objects (clubs, tools) and move immediately to the lowest elevation.
Example: Boat - If on water, drop anchor, seek a cabin, and stay low. Place a blanket over electronics.
dos: Keep the windows of a vehicle closed.
Wait 30 minutes after the last clap of thunder before leaving shelter.
Call for help for a strike victim immediately.
donts: Don't use a tree or fence as shelter.
Don't lie flat on the ground (increases contact surface).
Don't touch metal objects during the storm.

survivalGuides.title: Making and Using Natural Pitch/Glue
survivalGuides.description: Method for creating strong, waterproof glue (pitch) from pine sap, essential for hafting tool heads (axes, spears) and patching containers/shelter materials.
quickSteps: 1. Collect pine, fir, or spruce pitch/sap (a sticky resin).
2. Heat the sap to melt and purify it (remove debris).
3. Mix the pitch with finely powdered charcoal and a binder (animal dung/fibers).
4. Apply while warm and allow to cool/harden.

fullSteps.detail: Collect the sticky resin that oozes from damaged pine, fir, or spruce trees. Collect enough to fill a small container.
Gently heat the pitch in a non-flammable container until it melts into a liquid. Skim off impurities (bark, needles). Let it cool slightly before mixing.

Mix the liquid pitch with finely crushed charcoal (powdered wood ash). This adds strength. For a more flexible glue, mix in a small amount of fine animal hair, dried dung fibers, or powdered dry leaves.
Apply the pitch mixture while it is warm and sticky (but not hot enough to burn). Once cool, the pitch will harden. Store excess pitch in small cakes, wrapped in leaves or bark.

examples: Example: Hafting - Heat the handle and the tool head (axe, spear point) before applying the pitch to ensure a strong bond that won't crack during drying.
Example: Waterproofing - Apply a thin layer of pitch over seams or small tears in containers or shelter material.
dos: Heat the pitch gently; it is flammable.
Use fine, clean charcoal dust for strength.
Ensure the surfaces to be glued are clean and dry.
donts: Don't use the pitch directly on open wounds.
Don't heat the pitch over an open flame (use coals).
Don't rely on the pitch for load-bearing joints without lashing.

survivalGuides.title: Dealing with Animal Predators (Bears/Cougars)
survivalGuides.description: Protocol for deterring and defending against common large North American predators (bears and cougars), emphasizing preventative measures and appropriate response.
quickSteps: 1. Secure all food 100 yards from camp and shelter.
2. Make noise while traveling (bear bells, talking).
3. If seen, stand tall, make noise, and don't run.
4. Use bear spray if the animal gets within 30 feet.

fullSteps.detail: Store food, garbage, and scented items (toothpaste, sunscreen) in bear-proof containers or hang them from a tree branch at least 10 feet high and 4 feet away from the trunk.
Identify the bear type: **Black Bear** - Fight back aggressively. **Grizzly/Brown Bear** - Play dead (lie flat on stomach, cover neck) unless the attack is prolonged or predatory.
Always fight back aggressively. Cougars are often predatory. Stand tall, spread arms to look bigger, yell, and throw rocks/sticks. Protect your head and neck.
Keep bear spray accessible (not in your pack). Carry a sturdy hiking pole or stick. Never approach or follow an animal, especially one with cubs or a fresh kill.

examples: Example: Bluff Charge - If a bear charges and stops short, it is usually a bluff. Stand your ground and talk calmly until it leaves.
Example: Tent - If a bear approaches your tent, yell, clap, and make noise immediately from inside; do not stay silent.
dos: Carry bear spray and know how to use it.
Travel in groups if possible.
Make noise to alert animals to your presence.
donts: Don't run or climb a tree (most bears climb well).
Don't leave food or garbage near your camp.
Don't approach cubs or a carcass.

survivalGuides.title: Making and Using a Basic Atlatl (Spear-Thrower)
survivalGuides.description: Instructions for building and using an atlatl (spear-thrower) to dramatically increase the velocity, range, and impact of a short hunting spear/dart, conserving energy.
quickSteps: 1. Select a sturdy, short handle for the atlatl (about 2 feet long).
2. Carve a hook (spur) at one end to catch the dart.
3. Create a short, flexible dart (spear) with a notch at the end.
4. Practice the throwing motion (flick of the wrist).

fullSteps.detail: The atlatl should be about 2 feet long. Carve a handle grip on one end and a small hook or 'spur' on the other. This spur engages the dart.
The dart (spear) should be lightweight, straight, and about 4 to 6 feet long. Carve a small notch in the back end of the dart for the atlatl spur to fit into.

Hold the dart parallel to the atlatl, with the spur seated in the dart's notch. The throwing motion uses the entire arm, accelerating into a sudden wrist snap, which is what gives the dart its high velocity.
Affix fletching (small feathers or leaves) to the back of the dart to stabilize its flight, similar to an arrow. Use natural pitch (ID 139) to secure them.

examples: Example: Efficiency - An atlatl can increase throwing speed by up to $100$ miles per hour and extend range, making it highly effective against medium-sized game.
Example: Material - Use dry, light wood for the dart (e.g., cane, reed, or bamboo) for best performance.
dos: Ensure the dart is straight and flexible.
Use a distinct wrist snap during the throw.
Practice aiming at a stationary target until proficient.
donts: Don't use a dart that is too heavy.
Don't throw with only arm strength (use the wrist snap).
Don't attempt to use the atlatl in dense brush.

survivalGuides.title: Navigating by Improvised Compass
survivalGuides.description: How to create a simple, floating compass using a magnetized needle (or metal wire) and a water surface to determine magnetic North when a real compass is unavailable.
quickSteps: 1. Magnetize a needle or small piece of metal (paperclip, wire).
2. Place the magnetized object on a floating item (leaf, piece of cork).
3. Float the item in a still pool of water (or a container).
4. The needle will slowly point to magnetic North.

fullSteps.detail: Rub the needle (or thin wire) repeatedly in the same direction with a magnetic source (e.g., a magnet, hair, silk, or fur). A continuous, fast, single-direction rub is key.
Find a piece of light, buoyant material (small leaf, cork, a piece of bark). It must be flat and dry. Carefully lay the magnetized needle across the surface.
Place the floating item in a small pool of *still* water. Ensure there are no currents or wind disturbing the surface. The needle will slowly align itself with the Earth's magnetic field.
Once the needle settles, mark the North direction. Use this reference point to begin following a bearing (always remembering to adjust for magnetic declination if known).

examples: Example: Magnetizing Alternative - Use a piece of silk or synthetic fabric and rub the needle quickly against it to build static electricity (less reliable).
Example: Water - Use a small, stable container (like a helmet or cup) for the water, away from metal objects.
dos: Rub the needle in one direction only.
Keep the compass away from all metal objects.
Use still water and protect it from the wind.
donts: Don't let the needle sink or touch the sides of the container.
Don't attempt to use this method in a moving body of water.
Don't mistake the pointed end for North (you must test it).

survivalGuides.title: Making and Using a Debris Basket
survivalGuides.description: A basic weaving technique (coiling or plaiting) for creating functional baskets and containers from natural materials (reeds, grasses, flexible saplings) for carrying and storing.
quickSteps: 1. Gather long, flexible plant materials (vines, reeds, willow branches).
2. Soak the materials to increase flexibility.
3. Begin the base with a tight, circular weave.
4. Coil or plait the material upward to form the walls.

fullSteps.detail: Choose material that is flexible and sturdy when bent (e.g., willow, stripped inner bark, long grasses, cattail leaves). Soak the material in water for several hours to prevent cracking during weaving.
Create a strong core bundle. Start weaving around the core in a tight coil (coiling method) or lay strips perpendicular and begin interweaving (plaiting method) to create a firm base.
Angle the weaving upward as the diameter increases. Maintain a tight weave to increase the basket's durability and ability to hold finer debris or food items.

fullSteps.step: Step 4: Finishing the Rim and Handle
fullSteps.detail: Secure the top edge with a heavy, tightly woven rim (often using a tougher, stiff material). Attach a strong vine or cordage handle for carrying.

examples: Example: Waterproofing - Coat the inside of a finished basket with natural pine pitch (ID 139) or clay to make it waterproof for collecting water.
Example: Coiling - The coiling method (sewing loops of core material together with a flexible stringer) often creates a more rigid and durable container.
dos: Use materials that are uniform in thickness.
Weave tightly for strength and longevity.
Soak the materials before weaving.
donts: Don't use overly brittle, dry, or rotten materials.
Don't rely on a hastily woven basket for heavy or wet items.
Don't weave a handle from weak material.

survivalGuides.title: Treating Cold Injuries (Frostbite and Hypothermia)
survivalGuides.description: Critical steps for identifying and safely treating both localized cold injuries (frostbite) and systemic cold exposure (hypothermia).
quickSteps: 1. Move victim to a warm, dry shelter.
2. Remove all wet clothing immediately.
3. Warm the body core first (Hypothermia).
4. Only rewarm frostbitten areas if refreezing is NOT a risk.

fullSteps.detail: Mild symptoms: shivering, confusion. Severe symptoms: no shivering, loss of consciousness, slow pulse. **Goal: Warm the core.** Give warm, sweet drinks (if conscious). Use warm compresses/blankets on the chest, neck, and armpits.
Skin is white, waxy, and hard; the area is numb. If there is *any* risk of refreezing, do NOT rewarm the area. Cover gently and protect from further damage.

Once in a safe shelter (no risk of refreezing), submerge the frostbitten area in water that is comfortably warm ($104^\circ\text{F}$ to $108^\circ\text{F}$ / $40^\circ\text{C}$ to $42^\circ\text{C}$). Stop when skin is soft and flushed.
Cover the re-warmed area with dry, sterile, non-adhesive bandages. Keep the digits separated. The area will be painful and swollen. Seek medical help for pain relief and infection.

examples: Example: Mild Hypothermia - Give warm, high-calorie food/drinks and exercise gently (if strength allows) to generate internal heat.
Example: Rewarming - Never rub frostbitten skin; this causes tissue damage.
dos: Remove all wet clothing.
Keep the victim horizontal and still (especially in severe hypothermia).
Warm the patient from the core outward.
donts: Don't give alcohol or caffeine.
Don't rub or massage frostbitten areas.
Don't rewarm a frostbitten limb if it will refreeze.

survivalGuides.title: Typhoon/Hurricane Preparation and Lockdown
survivalGuides.description: Essential steps for securing a home, preparing for extended power loss, and protecting life during the approach and landfall of a major tropical cyclone (Typhoon/Hurricane/Cyclone).
quickSteps: 1. Secure/store all outdoor items (lawn furniture, trash cans).
2. Board up or shutter windows and reinforced doors.
3. Fill bathtubs and containers with clean water.
4. Follow all evacuation orders promptly.

fullSteps.detail: Install storm shutters or board up all windows and glass doors with plywood. Secure exterior doors with extra deadbolts or bracing. Secure loose roofing materials.
Turn off propane tanks. Fill vehicle gas tanks. Store a 3-day supply of drinking water (1 gallon per person/day) and fill bathtubs/sinks for non-drinking needs (flushing toilets).
Designate an interior room on the lowest floor, away from windows (a bathroom or closet). Store your Go-Bag (ID 208) here, along with a battery-powered radio and emergency lighting.
Stay indoors, stay away from windows, and monitor official weather alerts. If the eye passes, be aware that the calm will be followed by extreme winds from the opposite direction.

examples: Example: Water - Use a water purification method (ID 136, 219) for any water gathered from uncertain sources.
Example: Identification - Place critical documents (IDs, insurance) in waterproof bags inside the Go-Bag.
dos: Elevate valuable items above potential flood levels.
Keep cell phones and power banks fully charged.
Secure pet supplies and carriers.
donts: Don't venture outside during the eye of the storm.
Don't use candles (use battery lights).
Don't drive through floodwaters.

survivalGuides.title: Tsunami Warning and Evacuation Protocol
survivalGuides.description: Immediate life-saving actions to take upon receiving an official tsunami warning or observing natural signs of an impending large wave.
quickSteps: 1. Recognize natural signs (severe earthquake, rapidly receding water).
2. Move immediately to high ground (at least 100 feet above sea level).
3. Walk, don't drive (traffic will be congested).
4. Stay on high ground until authorities declare it safe.

fullSteps.detail: A powerful earthquake that makes standing difficult, a loud roar from the ocean, or the ocean water quickly pulling back (receding) from the shore are natural tsunami warnings. **Do not wait for an official alert.**

fullSteps.step: Step 2: Immediate Vertical and Horizontal Evacuation
fullSteps.detail: Immediately move inland and uphill to the highest point possible. If evacuation routes are marked, follow them. If possible, seek a sturdy, tall building (above the third floor) for vertical evacuation.
A tsunami is often a series of waves, sometimes hours apart. The first wave may not be the largest. Do not return to the coast after the first wave passes.
Check on others in the immediate vicinity. Once safe, use short text messages or social media to communicate rather than making phone calls to keep lines open for emergency services.

examples: Example: Vertical Evacuation - The lower floors of reinforced concrete hotels or hospitals are sometimes designated safe zones if sufficient high ground is unavailable.
Example: Danger - A receding ocean is not an opportunity to collect fish or shells; it is the final warning of the approaching wave crest.
dos: Move quickly on foot; don't rely on vehicles.
Stay at least 100 feet above sea level.
Grab only essential items (Go-Bag, medicine).
donts: Don't go to the coast to watch the tsunami.
Don't return to the shore until all official warnings are canceled.
Don't use weak structures (wooden shacks, bridges) for shelter.

survivalGuides.title: Making Fire with Improvised Lenses
survivalGuides.description: Using objects like plastic bottles, ice, or transparent materials to focus the sun's energy into a beam hot enough to ignite fine tinder.
quickSteps: 1. Find a clear, smooth, convex lens (magnifying glass, glasses, camera lens).
2. Hold the lens perpendicular to the sun's rays.
3. Focus the light to the smallest, brightest point on the tinder.
4. Blow gently on the smoking spot.

fullSteps.detail: Use a clear plastic bottle filled with clean water, a clear plastic bag filled with water tied into a sphere, the lens from a pair of glasses, or the curved bottom of a glass bottle.
Carve a piece of clear ice into a convex lens shape (thicker in the middle). Smooth the surfaces by warming them with your hand. Use the ice lens to focus sunlight.

Hold the lens steady until the projected point of light (the focal point) is the size of a pinhead. Ensure the focal point is resting on the finest, darkest tinder available (e.g., char cloth, charred bark, finely scraped wood dust).
Maintain the focused beam until the tinder begins to smoke and a small coal forms. Transfer the coal to a larger tinder nest and blow gently to create a flame.

examples: Example: Water Bottle - Squeeze the plastic bottle slightly to change the curvature and find the best focal point for the sun.
Example: Optimal Tinder - Dark, dry char cloth (ID 134) is the best target for solar ignition.
dos: Use the finest, darkest tinder possible.
Keep your hands steady during the focusing process.
Use this method on a clear, sunny day.
donts: Don't stare directly at the sun while focusing.
Don't attempt this method on a cloudy day.
Don't use dirty water or scratched plastic (it diffuses the light).

survivalGuides.title: Safe Foraging: The Rules of Threes for Berries
survivalGuides.description: General, non-definitive guidelines to increase safety when foraging wild berries and fruits by avoiding colors and plant features commonly associated with toxicity.
quickSteps: 1. Never eat white, yellow, or variegated berries.
2. Be wary of berries with milky or sap-filled interiors.
3. Avoid berries that hang in clusters of three.
4. Always identify a plant with 100% certainty before eating.

fullSteps.detail: While black and blue/purple berries are generally safer (e.g., blueberries, elderberries, blackberries), and red berries are a mixed group, white and yellow berries are most often poisonous (e.g., baneberry, white mistletoe).
Avoid berries that contain sticky, milky, or discolored sap when crushed. These often indicate toxic compounds. Seeds that are particularly large or oddly shaped should also raise caution.
Avoid berries that grow on hairy or thorny plants, or plants with deep red coloration on the stems/leaves. Berries that look like they've been eaten by animals are not necessarily safe for humans.
Use the Universal Edibility Test (ID 129) if absolutely necessary. If a berry is known to be edible but bitter or irritating, boiling it may help, but this is rare for true berries.

examples: Example: Edible - Raspberries and Blackberries (members of the Rubus family) are reliably edible worldwide. Their leaves are often toothed.
Example: Poisonous - The vast majority of small, tomato-like berries in the Nightshade (Solanaceae) family are highly toxic.
dos: Focus on berries with a smooth, dark blue/black color.
Be certain of the plant (leaf shape, stem, thorns) before tasting.
Wash all foraged food with purified water.
donts: Don't rely on the 'animal test' (birds and mammals can eat things humans cannot).
Don't eat berries that have a soapy, extremely bitter, or burning taste.
Don't mix unknown berries with known edible ones.

survivalGuides.title: Improvised Rations: Pemmican and Jerky
survivalGuides.description: Methods for drying and preserving meat (jerky) and making pemmican (a high-calorie survival food) for lightweight, long-term storage.
quickSteps: 1. Obtain lean meat (game or domestic).
2. Slice meat thinly (1/4 inch) for jerky.
3. Dry meat completely over low heat or in the sun.
4. For pemmican, mix ground jerky with melted fat and dried berries.

fullSteps.detail: Use very lean meat (fat spoils easily). Slice the meat thinly (about 1/4 inch or less) with the grain. Salt or cure the meat for several hours to aid preservation and flavor.
Suspend the slices over low heat (smoke is preferred, but not essential) or lay them on a clean, dry rock in the sun. The goal is to remove all moisture. Meat should snap when fully dried, not bend.
Grind the dried jerky into a fine powder. Melt animal fat (tallow or lard) and mix the powdered meat with the melted fat (ratio of 1 part meat powder to 1 part fat).
Stir in dried berries or nuts (optional). Press the mixture tightly into a container or mold it into bars. Allow it to cool and harden completely. Pemmican stores for years if kept cool and dry.

examples: Example: Flavoring - Use natural spices like wild onion, garlic, or small amounts of chili powder if available before drying the jerky.
Example: Storage - Store jerky and pemmican in airtight bags or containers, away from direct sunlight.
dos: Ensure the meat is completely free of fat before drying.
Dry the meat as quickly as possible.
Wash hands and tools thoroughly before processing.
donts: Don't use fatty cuts of meat (it will go rancid).
Don't boil the fat when making pemmican (just melt it).
Don't store dried meat near moisture.

survivalGuides.title: Treating Puncture Wounds and Impalement
survivalGuides.description: Protocol for managing deep, narrow wounds (puncture) and stabilizing an impaled object until professional medical help is available.
quickSteps: 1. Do not remove the impaled object.
2. Call for professional medical help.
3. Stabilize the object with bulky dressings.
4. Apply pressure around the wound, not on the object.

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Do Not Remove the Object
fullSteps.detail: The impaled object may be stopping major bleeding by plugging a severed vessel. Removing it can cause rapid, life-threatening hemorrhage.

Apply direct pressure with gauze or a clean cloth around the wound edges, avoiding pressure on the object itself. If on a limb, be prepared to use a tourniquet if external bleeding is massive (ID 203).

Use bulky dressings (bandages, clean cloth) to completely surround and secure the object, preventing it from moving or shifting. Tape the dressings tightly in place, ensuring the object is held rigidly.

Treat the victim for shock (ID 212). Monitor pulse and breathing. Transport the victim to definitive medical care immediately, ensuring the object is protected from accidental movement during transport.

examples: Example: Small Puncture - For non-impaled puncture wounds, clean thoroughly with purified water, allow to bleed slightly to flush bacteria, and cover. Seek tetanus shot.
Example: Eyeball Impalement - Cover both eyes with dressings (the uninjured eye must be covered because eye movement is linked). Stabilize the object gently.
dos: Stabilize the object to prevent movement.
Treat for shock immediately.
Check the wound site for signs of infection later (redness, heat, pus).
donts: Don't attempt to remove the object.
Don't probe or clean the wound deeply (risk of driving bacteria further in).
Don't give the victim food or drink.

survivalGuides.title: Basic Lashing and Shelter Joinery
survivalGuides.image: [Image showing a square lashing securing two logs]
survivalGuides.description: Essential lashing techniques (Square, Diagonal, Tripod) using natural cordage (ID 213) or rope to securely join branches and poles for building rigid shelters and rafts.
quickSteps: 1. Start with a Clove Hitch (ID 222) on one pole.
2. Use the Square Lashing for poles that meet at a $90^\circ$ angle.
3. Use the Diagonal Lashing for poles that cross at an angle.
4. Finish the lashing with a frapping turn and a secure knot (ID 222).

fullSteps.detail: Secure the cordage to one pole using a Clove Hitch (ID 222) or a Timber Hitch. Ensure the knot is tight and at the start of the joining area.
Wrap the cordage around the two poles (meeting at $90^\circ$) in alternating directions 3-4 times. Then, pull the rope tightly between the poles (frapping turns) to tighten the entire structure.
Begin with a Timber Hitch. Wrap the cordage around the poles diagonally in both directions (like an 'X' on top of an 'X'). Use frapping turns to tighten the intersection.
End the lashing by using a Clove Hitch around the pole next to the joint. Ensure the final knot is pulled extremely tight to hold the tension.

examples: Example: Frapping - The frapping turn (wrapping the rope around the lashings themselves) is the most critical step for making the joint rigid.
Example: Material - Use strong, non-stretching cordage (paracord is ideal) or well-made natural cordage.
dos: Maintain high tension throughout the wrapping process.
Lash poles together, rather than trying to cut joints (saves time and effort).
Use rigid, straight poles for structural integrity.
donts: Don't use weak, fraying cordage.
Don't skip the frapping turns.
Don't use these lashings for swinging loads.

survivalGuides.title: Finding Water by Following Wildlife
survivalGuides.description: Using animal behavior, insect patterns, and vegetation type as reliable biological indicators for locating natural water sources in arid or unknown terrain.
quickSteps: 1. Look for animal trails/tracks leading downhill or converging.
2. Follow birds in the early morning or late afternoon.
3. Look for specific green vegetation (willow, cattail).
4. Search for insects (bees, non-biting flies) that stay near water.

fullSteps.detail: Animals follow the path of least resistance to water. Look for clear, converging trails leading downhill. Check low points, depressions, and the outside bends of dry creek beds.
Avoid birds that feed on berries (they get moisture from food). Look for flocking birds (pigeons, finches) flying straight and low in the morning or evening. They often fly to water sources.
Identify specific water-loving trees (willow, cottonwood, sycamore) or water plants (cattails, reeds). Dig at the base of these plants in a dry streambed—water may be shallow underground.
Mosquitoes, biting flies, and blood-sucking insects are not reliable. Look for bees (they rarely venture far from water) and specific non-biting flies that congregate near surface water.

examples: Example: Dew/Fog - Collect dew from grass or rock surfaces in the early morning using a clean cloth or garment.
Example: Digging - In dry creek beds, dig a small 'seep' hole about 2-3 feet deep; water may slowly seep into the hole for collection.
dos: Follow trails going downhill.
Look for the brightest, greenest vegetation in an area.
Always purify collected water before drinking (ID 219).
donts: Don't follow carnivorous animals (they may lead to danger).
Don't rely solely on insect signs.
Don't waste water on non-essential tasks.

survivalGuides.title: Survival Priorities: The Rule of Threes
survivalGuides.image: [Image showing three stick figures next to fire, shelter, and water]
survivalGuides.description: The fundamental 'Rule of Threes' prioritizing the immediate hierarchy of survival needs (Air, Shelter, Water, Food) to guide decision-making in an emergency.
quickSteps: 1. 3 Minutes without Air.
2. 3 Hours without Shelter (in extreme environments).
3. 3 Days without Water.
4. 3 Weeks without Food.

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Focus on Immediate Danger (3 Minutes)
fullSteps.detail: If breathing is compromised (choking, drowning, injury), this must be addressed immediately (First Aid: ID 201, 207). Panic control is also a top priority.
In severe heat or cold, building shelter (ID 205) or finding cover is the next most urgent step to prevent hyperthermia or hypothermia (ID 221, 144). Fire is secondary to shelter for warmth.
Water is the third priority. Locating, filtering, and purifying water (ID 219) is a vital task once shelter is secured and temperature is stabilized.
Food is the lowest priority; the body can survive weeks without it. Focus on passive gathering (traps, foraging ID 129, 214) to conserve energy.

examples: Example: Decision-Making - If you are lost in a blizzard, shelter and fire take precedence over everything else.
Example: Mental State - Maintaining a positive and calm mental state is as crucial as physical needs, as panic drastically reduces survival time.
dos: Address needs in the correct priority order.
Stay in one place if injured or lost until shelter is built.
Always assess the environment before starting any task.
donts: Don't panic (it wastes time and oxygen).
Don't prioritize food gathering over shelter or water.
Don't start walking aimlessly.

survivalGuides.title: Making and Using Activated Charcoal
survivalGuides.description: How to create an effective form of activated charcoal (carbon powder) for emergency treatment of internal poisoning by absorbing ingested toxins.
quickSteps: 1. Obtain hardwood material (no resin).
2. Burn the wood until it becomes clean, black charcoal (no ash).
3. Grind the charcoal into a very fine powder.
4. Mix the powder with purified water for consumption.

fullSteps.detail: Burn clean pieces of hardwood (e.g., maple, oak, willow) in a fire. Let the wood burn completely until it is entirely black and cooled. Do not use softwoods (pine, cedar) or briquettes.
Grind the cooled charcoal into the finest powder possible (use two rocks or pound it with a heavy object). The finer the powder, the better its absorption capacity.
While not truly 'activated' in the lab sense, mixing the fine powder with water creates a carbon slurry that can bind toxins. Mix with purified water until it forms a thin, drinkable paste.

If you suspect ingestion of certain poisons (many pesticides, certain plant toxins), drink a large quantity of the slurry immediately. Charcoal does not work for all poisons (e.g., corrosives, alcohol, petroleum products).

examples: Example: Stomach Pain - Activated charcoal can help settle a severely upset stomach or treat mild food poisoning (if the source is bacterial).
Example: Dose - A typical emergency dose is several tablespoons of the powder mixed into a glass of water.
dos: Use only clean, food-grade charcoal.
Grind the powder as fine as flour.
Drink plenty of water afterward.
donts: Don't use charcoal if the victim is unconscious.
Don't use charcoal if the poisoning is from corrosive acids or alkalis.
Don't delay medical transport if a serious poisoning is suspected.

survivalGuides.title: Zombie Apocalypse: Tactical Priorities
survivalGuides.description: Tactical priorities for immediate survival during a zombie outbreak, focusing on the hierarchy of needs unique to the threat (Head Trauma, Infection Control, Noise Discipline).
quickSteps: 1. Prioritize Head Trauma: Only head shots neutralize the threat.
2. Maintain Strict Noise Discipline to avoid hordes.
3. Institute Quarantine and Amputation protocols for bite wounds.
4. Secure a defensible, multi-story structure for long-term operations.

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Threat Neutralization (The Rule of the Head)
fullSteps.detail: Understand that the primary weakness is the brain/central nervous system. All tactical decisions, from weapon choice to engagement style, must prioritize destruction of the skull/brain. Avoid body shots.

High noise levels (gunfire, yelling, sirens) attract large groups (hordes). Use silenced weapons or quiet melee tools (blunt objects, axes) whenever possible. Travel lightly and avoid high-density urban areas.

Any bite, scratch, or contact with fluids from the infected must be treated as potential exposure. Institute a mandatory $15$-minute observation period for all wounds. If a bite is confirmed, immediate, clean amputation above the wound site may be the only remedy.

Secure a defensible location that offers a single point of entry, clear sightlines, and multiple means of escape (e.g., a rooftop). Water and food storage must be secured *before* the area is locked down. Barricade all lower windows and doors.

examples: Example: Weapons - High-power firearms are loud and attract hordes; use them only for clearing an escape path. Melee weapons like crowbars or sharpened shovels are superior for silent travel.
Example: Defense - Use furniture, wire, or debris to create barriers and bottlenecks to slow the enemy flow toward the single entry point.
dos: Wear protective clothing (leather, denim) to minimize skin exposure.
Always travel with at least one partner (the 'Two-Person Rule').
Keep a full Go-Bag (ID 208) prepared at all times.
donts: Don't travel on busy roads or near hospitals (high initial infection points).
Don't waste limited ammunition on non-critical targets.
Don't assume a downed zombie is dead; always double-tap the head.

survivalGuides.title: Deep Forest Survival (Lost in Dense Woods)
survivalGuides.description: The immediate 'S.T.O.P.' protocol for becoming lost in dense forest, emphasizing staying put, signaling, and utilizing forest resources efficiently.
quickSteps: 1. S.T.O.P.: Stop, Think, Observe, Plan.
2. Establish a clear, visible base camp immediately.
3. Collect water and fire materials (focus on dry wood).
4. Create large, high-visibility ground signals (X or SOS).

fullSteps.detail: Stop immediately upon realizing you are lost. Avoid wandering. Build a small, temporary shelter and start a fire in a visible, open area to serve as your central 'hub' (ID 205).
If near a potential search path (river, road), hike parallel to it. Otherwise, stay put and create large ground-to-air signals. Use three signal fires (ID 218) or three whistle blasts.
Prioritize locating a water source (ID 152). Collect and purify water (ID 219) before doing anything else. Forage for low-risk foods like insects (ID 126) or known safe plants (ID 129).
Do not attempt to 'bushwhack' through dense undergrowth (wastes massive energy). Use existing animal trails or follow water bodies.

examples: Example: Visibility - Clear a large area around your fire and shelter. Hang brightly colored clothing or material from tall trees.
Example: Direction - Use the shadow-stick method (ID 128) or improvised compass (ID 142) to maintain a general direction if you must travel.
dos: Stay near water sources.
Light a fire immediately for warmth and signaling.
Leave notes/markers indicating your direction if you must leave the base camp.
donts: Don't panic and wander.
Don't travel at night or during low visibility.
Don't rely solely on foraging; focus on traps/snares (ID 214) to save energy.

survivalGuides.title: Survival Trapped in a Collapsed Structure
survivalGuides.description: Immediate actions for survival when trapped under rubble or in a confined space, focusing on self-rescue, signaling, and conserving resources.
quickSteps: 1. Protect the mouth and nose (dust, debris).
2. Assess injuries and administer self-first aid (ID 201).
3. Signal continuously (whistle, tapping, yelling).
4. Conserve energy and water; do not move heavy debris.

fullSteps.detail: Cover your mouth and nose with a piece of cloth to filter dust. Control panic; panicking wastes precious oxygen and energy. Focus on breathing rhythmically.
Use a whistle if available (three blasts is distress). If no whistle, tap on pipes or solid metal/concrete three times, waiting for a minute, and repeating. Do not yell continuously; it exhausts you.
Only attempt to move light debris if it creates immediate access to a safe exit or more space. Do not attempt to move anything heavy or structural; this risks further collapse.
Lie still to minimize oxygen consumption. If water is available, ration it carefully. If you see light, use a reflective object (mirror, glass, phone screen) to signal its source.

examples: Example: Time - Tap on debris in rhythmic patterns during lulls in outside noise (morning and evening are best times for rescuers to hear).
Example: Movement - If you must move, shuffle debris slowly and listen for shifting structural sounds.
dos: Signal only when you hear signs of rescue activity.
Keep your phone/flashlight off to save battery.
Wrap up in any available material to stay warm.
donts: Don't light fires (risk of oxygen depletion/explosion).
Don't use matches or lighters (if gas leaks are present).
Don't move heavy or load-bearing debris.

survivalGuides.title: Plane Crash Survival (Post-Impact)
survivalGuides.description: The 'Impact, Evacuate, Secure' protocol for surviving a plane crash, focusing on fire hazard control and establishing immediate shelter/signaling.
quickSteps: 1. Unbuckle and evacuate the plane immediately (risk of fire).
2. Move at least 100 yards upwind of the wreckage.
3. Attend to the injured and secure the crash site.
4. Salvage key survival gear from the wreckage (metal, fabric, medical kit).

fullSteps.detail: Get out as quickly as possible. The primary post-crash threat is fire (fuel). Move away from any leaking fuel or smoke. Stay upwind of the wreckage.
Triage injured passengers (ID 201). Gather all survivors. Appoint a leader and ensure everyone remains calm. Do not allow survivors to wander off.

The wreckage is your most visible signal. Stay near it unless fire or extreme danger forces you away. Salvage all useful items: plane seats for insulation, metal for signaling/tools, medical kit, fire extinguishers, and blankets.
Set up a temporary shelter using salvaged materials. Use the plane's shiny fuselage (if intact) or aluminum foil for signaling (ID 218). Create a visible distress signal (SOS or X) near the wreckage.

examples: Example: Water - Do not drink fluids from the plane (fuel contamination). Use the cabin insulation for warmth/shelter.
Example: Rescue - Planes often follow flight paths; look for potential lines of travel or civilization, but stay put near the wreckage until supplies are secure.
dos: Move quickly to a safe distance.
Salvage the aircraft's first aid kit and blankets.
Assign lookouts to listen for search planes.
donts: Don't smoke or use open flames near the wreckage.
Don't wander away from the crash site.
Don't separate from the main group.

survivalGuides.title: Car Crash Survival (Remote Area)
survivalGuides.description: The protocol for a serious car crash in a remote location, utilizing the vehicle as the primary resource for shelter, signaling, and supply.
quickSteps: 1. Check for fuel leaks and fire hazards; disconnect the battery.
2. Administer first aid to all occupants (ID 201).
3. Salvage all useful gear from the car (jack, tools, seats, wiring).
4. Stay with the vehicle; it is your shelter and signal.

fullSteps.step: Step 1: Safety and Immediate Hazard Control
fullSteps.detail: Turn off the ignition. Disconnect the battery if wiring is exposed or you smell fuel. Check all occupants for injury (spinal injury is a risk—do not move the victim unless absolutely necessary).

The vehicle is the best shelter and is easily spotted. If necessary, use the jack and tools to dismantle non-essential parts (wiring for snares/cordage, seats for insulation, gas/fluid from the tank).

If you are off-road, use the hood or roof as a signaling mirror (ID 218). Place reflective material (mirrors, chrome pieces) high in a tree near the car. Use the horn in bursts (three blasts) if you hear traffic.
Do not leave the vehicle unless you are absolutely certain of civilization's proximity. Leave notes in the car detailing your direction of travel and destination if you must leave (ID 202).

examples: Example: Windows - If the vehicle is undamaged, crack the window slightly to avoid suffocating from exhaust/fumes while using the heater for warmth.
Example: Resources - The oil can be used for fire-starting; the washer fluid reservoir contains water (often contaminated but potentially usable).
dos: Stay with the vehicle until rescue is imminent.
Gather water and prepare fire materials immediately.
Use the seat padding for insulation.
donts: Don't attempt to drive a severely damaged vehicle.
Don't move a victim with a suspected spinal injury.
Don't use the headlights continuously (drains battery quickly).

survivalGuides.title: Boat Crash/Capsizing (Coastal/River)
survivalGuides.description: Immediate life-saving steps upon a boat capsizing or sinking near land, prioritizing PFD use, staying with the wreckage, and reaching shore.
quickSteps: 1. Put on PFD/life vest immediately.
2. Stay with the boat (if floating/partially sunk) to increase visibility.
3. Assess the distance to shore and current/wave conditions.
4. If swimming, do so slowly to conserve heat (ID 137).

fullSteps.detail: Ensure everyone has a flotation device. Take a headcount. If the boat is sinking, grab a Go-Bag (ID 208) if possible. Stay calm.
The boat wreckage is easier to spot than a person. Cling to the hull or largest floating piece. If in a group, huddle (ID 137) to conserve warmth.
Only swim to shore if you can clearly see the shore, the distance is short, and you have flotation. In rivers, always swim *with* the current and aim for the inside bend of the river (slower water).
Once on land, treat for hypothermia (ID 144) immediately. If saltwater exposure occurred, flush eyes and wash skin with fresh water if available.

examples: Example: Gear - The boat battery or lights can be used for signaling. Plastic containers (coolers, bins) make excellent flotation aids.
Example: Signaling - Use a flare (if available) or mirror (ID 218) while you are still high in the water near the wreckage.
dos: Stay dry if possible.
Throw all available floating objects overboard.
Protect your feet and head from the cold.
donts: Don't remove clothing in cold water.
Don't drink seawater (ID 137).
Don't swim against a strong current.

survivalGuides.title: Stranded with Cannibals (Tactical Escape)
survivalGuides.description: Extreme escape tactics for survival when captured or threatened by hostile groups or isolated human populations with lethal intent.
quickSteps: 1. Maintain submissive but observant demeanor; do not provoke.
2. Assess security (restraints, guards, escape routes).
3. Conceal or acquire a silent weapon (knife, sharp rock, fire).
4. Escape during a distraction or when security is at its lowest (deep night).

fullSteps.detail: Observe daily routines: guard changes, sleep cycles, weapon storage, food prep. Identify the leader and the weakest link in the security. Locate tools or small items that can be used as weapons.
If possible, find or fashion a silent, close-quarters weapon (sharpened bone, shard of glass, fire-hardened stick). Conceal it well. Focus on defensive escape, not offensive combat.

The best time to escape is usually during a meal, a shift change, or between 02:00 and 04:00 (when guards are least alert). Be prepared to be loud for only the brief moment needed to neutralize restraints.
Move immediately into the densest cover available (swamp, thick forest). Travel fast and far for the first 24 hours. Use counter-tracking measures (walking in water, doubling back).

examples: Example: Restraints - Use friction (a piece of wire or stiff vine) sawed back and forth against rope restraints. Use oil or fat to help slip out of metal restraints.
Example: Distraction - Cause a fire, loud noise, or structural collapse in an area away from your exit to draw attention.
dos: Be patient; wait for the perfect moment.
Remain calm and conserve energy.
Identify and secure clean water first thing after escaping.
donts: Don't engage in conversation that may escalate tension.
Don't attempt an escape during daylight or if fully exposed.
Don't leave easy tracks to follow.

survivalGuides.title: Evasion of a Haunting Spirit (Ghost)
survivalGuides.description: Strategies for dealing with hostile, non-physical entities, emphasizing psychological defense, breaking line of sight, and environmental disruption.
quickSteps: 1. Identify the spirit's domain (object, room, area).
2. Avoid direct confrontation or acknowledgment.
3. Create psychological barriers (light, loud sound).
4. Focus entirely on rapid, clean evacuation of the area.

fullSteps.detail: Observe what the entity reacts to: Is it bound to an object (salt line, religious symbol)? Does it only manifest in darkness? This provides the means of temporary defense.

Maintain strong mental focus; fear feeds the entity. Avoid acknowledging its presence or engaging in communication. Use light (flashlights, fire) and loud, rhythmic, non-emotional noise to disrupt its focus.

Use complex, fast, and multi-directional movement to avoid being followed. Spirits often rely on tracking. Use mirrors (which may confuse or reflect) and complex architecture (stairs, closets) to lose pursuit.
If the entity is tied to a specific object (anchor), the fastest method is to destroy or remove that object from its domain. This is extremely high risk and requires preparation.

examples: Example: Barrier - Use common superstitions (salt, iron, holy water) to create temporary psychological barriers in doorways or windows during an escape plan.
Example: Evasion - Move to areas with high human traffic or activity, as strong emotions/crowds may disrupt the entity's ability to manifest.
dos: Maintain a calm, logical mindset.
Prioritize exit over investigation.
Have a backup light source (chemical light sticks, candles).
donts: Don't speak the spirit's name or history.
Don't get cornered in small, dark spaces.
Don't spend energy trying to reason with the entity.

survivalGuides.title: Evasion of a Wilderness Monster (Cryptid)
survivalGuides.description: Tactical methods for escaping an unknown, large, and potentially hostile creature, focusing on identifying senses, disrupting tracking, and utilizing verticality.
quickSteps: 1. Avoid engagement; prioritize escape over confrontation.
2. Identify the creature's primary sense (sight, sound, smell).
3. Move to terrain that limits its mobility (rocky, deep water).
4. Use fire and loud, sharp noises as a temporary deterrent.

fullSteps.detail: Observe how the creature hunts: If it is quiet, its hearing may be acute (make silent movements). If it has large eyes, move in darkness. If it relies on scent, cover your scent with mud, strong herbs, or water.
If the creature is large, move through dense areas, tight canyons, or climb high into trees (if it cannot climb). Use rocky, unstable terrain that requires precision to walk on.
Set up a noisy, smelly distraction in one direction (fire, food, loud radio/object) and move silently in the opposite direction. This buys critical time.
Fire is the ultimate deterrent. Build a large, smoky fire immediately. Use torches for temporary protection during movement. Most terrestrial creatures instinctively fear fire.

examples: Example: Tracking - Walk backwards in a short area, then jump or climb onto a rock to eliminate your trail (false trail).
Example: Weaponry - Focus on hitting soft spots (eyes, gills, mouth). Do not rely on conventional body shots unless the anatomy is known.
dos: Use dense foliage for cover.
Maintain silence and light discipline during movement.
Conserve energy for a sudden, decisive sprint.
donts: Don't confront a larger, unknown predator.
Don't travel on clear, easy trails.
Don't assume the creature has given up the chase.

survivalGuides.title: Survival Against a Witch/Possessor (The Accursed)
survivalGuides.description: Defense tactics against an intelligent, magically empowered human threat, focusing on breaking the enchantment, disrupting rituals, and targeting the source of power.
quickSteps: 1. Disbelieve the magical nature of the threat (psychological defense).
2. Identify and disrupt the source of power (talisman, ritual site).
3. Use fire or pure iron as a physical deterrent.
4. Escape the bounded area of influence.

fullSteps.detail: Witches often rely on fear, doubt, and suggestion. The primary defense is strong belief in logic and disbelief in the magic itself. Maintain a calm, unshakeable demeanor.

fullSteps.step: Step 2: Locating the Nexus of Power
fullSteps.detail: Witches' power is often localized (e.g., a specific house, object, or talisman). Your goal is to find the ritual site and destroy or neutralize the object of power. This must be done silently.
If possible, use materials known in folklore to be antithetical to magic: pure iron, running water (crossing a stream), certain plants (sage, hemlock), or intense heat (fire).
Once free, travel to a well-populated or sacred area. Ensure you have not been 'marked' or contaminated; purify yourself with running water or fire (if safe to do so).

examples: Example: Defense - Salt (purification) or iron (warding) can be used to create temporary lines or physical obstacles.
Example: Communication - Never accept a 'gift' or drink offered by the witch, as it may be enchanted or poisoned.
dos: Use rational thinking to break enchantments.
Prioritize the destruction of the source of power.
Travel to a crowded, public space.
donts: Don't accept any food or drink from the enemy.
Don't fall into despair or fear (psychological attacks).
Don't allow the enemy to complete a ritual.

survivalGuides.title: Evacuating an Abandoned Haunted Building
survivalGuides.description: Protocols for immediate escape from a multi-story building that is physically crumbling and psychologically hostile, prioritizing structural integrity checks.
quickSteps: 1. Move immediately away from the source of the threat/noise.
2. Test all structural elements (floors, stairs) before applying full weight.
3. Travel only along load-bearing walls.
4. Create loud, sustained noise to disrupt any psychological effects.

fullSteps.detail: Assume all floors and stairs are unstable. Use a stick or foot to lightly tap or probe the floor ahead of you before stepping fully. Move only along exterior or central load-bearing walls.
Loud, consistent noise (a whistle, rhythmic pounding) disrupts both the hostile entity (ID 162) and psychological fear. It also allows you to hear the sound of the structure shifting.
Do not investigate the haunting; focus on the quickest exit. If debris blocks the path, move only small pieces. Use the 'Trapped' protocol (ID 157) if a collapse occurs.
Once outside, move at least 100 yards away from the building. Do not allow anyone to re-enter for any reason, as a hostile entity may attempt to lure victims back inside.

examples: Example: Visibility - Use bright lights pointed upward to assess ceiling safety and downward to check for holes/traps in the floor.
Example: Entrapment - If doors are locked/stuck, use a crowbar or heavy debris to pry open. Use windows only as a last resort, as the fall risk may be high.
dos: Look up and down constantly for structural hazards.
Maintain speed and momentum toward the exit.
Always test surfaces before stepping.
donts: Don't split up from your group.
Don't climb on unstable furniture.
Don't assume a dark patch on the floor is just a shadow (it could be a hole).

survivalGuides.title: Escape from Quicksand/Deep Mud
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for self-rescue from quicksand or deep, thick mud, focusing on maximizing buoyancy and minimizing vertical force.
quickSteps: 1. Stop all vertical movement immediately.
2. Drop all heavy gear (backpack, heavy boots).
3. Lean back and spread your body weight horizontally.
4. Slowly paddle or wiggle until you float to the surface.

fullSteps.detail: Do not panic; quicksand is rarely deeper than a few feet. Immediately drop your backpack or any heavy item. Do not try to pull your leg out (this creates a vacuum).
Lean back gently and widely, spreading your weight as much as possible across the surface. This is the most crucial step. You will begin to float because quicksand/mud is denser than water.
Once horizontal, slowly and gently paddle with your hands and feet to move toward the edge. Spend 10-15 minutes wiggling one leg free, then the other. Do not attempt a fast, vertical pull.
Once at the edge, roll completely out onto stable, solid ground. Do not stand up immediately. Crawl a short distance away before standing.

examples: Example: Stick Aid - If a long stick is available, lay it horizontally across the surface and press down gently to gain leverage while you lean back.
Example: Boots - If your boots feel stuck, it may be better to remove them (if safe) to reduce the vacuum effect.
dos: Remain calm and move slowly.
Spread your weight out wide.
Drop all heavy items immediately.
donts: Don't try to pull yourself out vertically.
Don't panic or struggle violently (you will sink faster).
Don't jump or move onto patches of seemingly unstable ground.

survivalGuides.title: Surviving a Severe Dust Storm
survivalGuides.description: Survival tactics during a haboob (dust storm) focusing on respiratory protection, visibility, and vehicle safety.
quickSteps: 1. Seek substantial shelter immediately (indoors or vehicle).
2. Cover your mouth and nose with a damp cloth.
3. If driving, pull over, turn off the engine, and turn off headlights.
4. Cover all electronics and sensitive gear.

fullSteps.detail: Dust storms cause severe respiratory irritation and visibility loss. Cover your mouth and nose with a damp cloth (bandana, shirt). Close all windows and vents immediately.
If driving, pull completely off the road. Turn off headlights; taillights may confuse other drivers into following you. Set the parking brake and wait it out.
If caught outside, move to a large rock, canyon wall, or deep ditch. Hunker down and use available material to cover all exposed skin and eyes. Visibility can drop to zero in seconds.

Wait several minutes after the dust seems to clear. Check all car air filters, electronics, and supplies for dust penetration. Check for 'valley fever' symptoms (fever, cough, rash) in the following days.

examples: Example: Glasses - If wearing glasses, wipe them gently with a damp cloth; dry wiping may scratch the lens.
Example: Eyes - Close your eyes completely or wear goggles. Dust particles cause painful corneal abrasions.
dos: Huddle low to the ground.
Turn off the car's exterior lights.
Protect your breathing passages.
donts: Don't continue driving.
Don't wear contact lenses.
Don't attempt to run or move quickly.

survivalGuides.title: Survival After Volcanic Eruption
survivalGuides.description: Survival tactics following a volcanic eruption, focusing on mitigating ash exposure, avoiding lava flow, and escaping toxic gas pockets.
quickSteps: 1. Seek immediate shelter indoors (if time permits).
2. Wear a mask or wet cloth over the mouth/nose.
3. Protect eyes from falling ash (goggles or closed eyes).
4. Travel perpendicular to the wind/lava flow.

fullSteps.detail: Volcanic ash is pulverized rock (sharp silica). Wear goggles. Use an N95 mask or, if unavailable, a damp cloth (moistened with purified water) to cover your nose and mouth.
Toxic gases $\left(\text{SO}_2, \text{CO}_2\right)$ are heavy and settle in low areas (valleys, pits). Travel on high ground and avoid low-lying depressions or caves.
Move immediately away from the volcano. Travel perpendicular (at a right angle) to the direction of the wind and any lava/pyroclastic flows. Cover all equipment/vehicles to protect from ash abrasion.
If sheltering indoors, seal off all windows and doors with duct tape or wet towels. Turn off HVAC and air conditioning systems. The ash can collapse flat roofs, so monitor ash buildup.

examples: Example: Water - Do not drink collected rainwater or water from open sources; it may be highly acidic or contaminated with ash/toxins.
Example: Lava - Lava flows slowly, but the heat emitted is immense. Always keep a safe, distant barrier between yourself and the flow.
dos: Wear long sleeves and pants.
Listen to official evacuation and alert warnings.
Use a hand-held compass (electronics may fail).
donts: Don't drive; ash is corrosive to engines.
Don't attempt to move through canyons or low depressions.
Don't wear contact lenses (ash will irritate and scratch the eye).

survivalGuides.title: Emergency Rope Ascending/Descending (Knots)
survivalGuides.description: Essential techniques (using Prusik and Blake's Hitches) for safely climbing up and down a fixed rope without mechanical ascenders/descenders, using only knots and webbing/cordage.
quickSteps: 1. Secure the main rope anchor (must be strong).
2. Create a foot loop and chest loop from accessory cordage.
