3. Attach the loops to the main rope using Prusik knots.
4. Move the knots in alternation (foot, then chest) to ascend/descend.

fullSteps.detail: Ensure the main rope is anchored to an immovable object (large tree, heavy beam). The rope must be rated for weight. Check the rope visually for cuts or damage.

The Prusik hitch is a friction knot that locks under load but can be moved when loose. Tie two separate loops of accessory cord (one for your foot/feet, one for a chest harness) onto the main rope using the Prusik hitch.
Move the foot Prusik up the rope. Stand up in the foot loop. While standing, slide the chest Prusik up. Sit down in the chest harness, slide the foot Prusik up, and repeat the standing motion.

Use a rappel friction device (if available) or a safe friction knot (like the Classic Figure 8 Descender Knot). Descend slowly, ensuring the friction knot is secured and tested before committing weight.

examples: Example: Cordage - Prusik cord should be 5mm to 6mm thick and rated strong enough for body weight.
Example: Safety - Always wear gloves; rope friction can cause severe burns.
dos: Test all knots before putting full weight on them.
Wear gloves for hand protection.
Move slowly and rhythmically.
donts: Don't use weak material for the main rope.
Don't attempt to free climb if the descent is more than 10 feet.
Don't descend without a friction device or friction knot.

survivalGuides.title: Treating Psychological Trauma (Triage)
survivalGuides.description: Immediate psychological first aid techniques to stabilize victims experiencing severe trauma, shock, or panic in a survival situation.
quickSteps: 1. Remove the victim from the immediate source of danger.
2. Use the 'Talk, Listen, Link' method (P.F.A.).
3. Reorient the victim to reality (current date, location).
4. Assign the victim a small, specific task to regain control.

fullSteps.detail: First, ensure the victim and yourself are physically safe. Move to a quiet, secure location with limited sensory input.
Use sensory techniques to ground the person in reality: Ask them to state 5 things they can see, 4 things they can touch, 3 things they can hear, 2 things they can smell, and 1 thing they can taste.

fullSteps.step: Step 3: Talk and Listen (Psychological First Aid)
fullSteps.detail: Do not force them to talk about the event. Listen to what they want to say without judgment. Offer non-judgmental comfort (a blanket, warm drink, or touch if appropriate).
Assign a simple, concrete task (e.g., 'Guard the supplies,' 'Sort the bandages'). Completing a task helps break the trauma cycle and gives the victim a sense of purpose and control.

examples: Example: Panic - If hyperventilating, have them breathe into a paper bag (if available) or cup their hands over their mouth/nose to slow breathing.
Example: Children - Maintain physical closeness, speak calmly, and simplify instructions.
dos: Validate their feelings ('It's okay to be scared').
Speak in a calm, steady voice.
Provide food, water, and rest.
donts: Don't tell them to 'calm down' or 'be brave'.
Don't use sarcasm or humor.
Don't leave a severely traumatized victim alone.

survivalGuides.title: Making Fire in Wet Conditions
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for finding and preparing dry tinder and kindling (punk wood, cedar bark) when all materials are damp or soaked from rain/snow.
quickSteps: 1. Find and create a dry working platform (rock, bark).
2. Seek 'inner wood' (heartwood) that remains dry inside logs.
3. Use a knife to create fine, dry 'feather sticks'.
4. Use a fatty, concentrated heat source (fatwood, birch bark) for ignition.

fullSteps.detail: Light the fire under a piece of overhanging rock, a large piece of bark, or inside a simple lean-to shelter. This protects the spark/flame from wind and rain.

Look for dead, standing trees (not those on the ground) and look for wood near the core of a rotten log (punk wood). Use a knife to shave the dry wood from the center of thick branches (the 'inner wood').
Use a sharp knife to carve long, thin, continuous curls of wood from dry inner sticks. These 'feather sticks' catch flame quickly and transfer heat to larger, damp kindling.
If available, look for birch bark (oils are highly flammable even when wet) or 'fatwood' (pine wood saturated with flammable resin). These are essential for wet starts.

examples: Example: Punk Wood - Rotten wood is highly absorbent, but if you find dry punk wood, it will catch a spark easily and smolder for a long time.
Example: Ignition - Use an accelerant (alcohol wipes, hand sanitizer, birch bark) if a friction method (ID 125) is necessary in damp conditions.
dos: Build a raised fire platform (rock or green logs).
Process a large quantity of dry material before lighting the spark.
Start small and dry, and move to large and damp.
donts: Don't rely on the outer bark or leaves.
Don't attempt friction fire (ID 125) with damp components.
Don't place the spark or coal directly on wet ground.

survivalGuides.title: Surviving a Mine/Cave Collapse
survivalGuides.description: Specific procedures for being trapped deep underground, focusing on air quality, geological stability, and communication with the outside.
quickSteps: 1. Stop; assess structural stability and listen for continuous falling debris.
2. Test air quality (smell, dizziness).
3. Signal continuously (tapping, whistling).
4. Remain in a safe pocket and conserve light/energy.

fullSteps.detail: Carbon monoxide and dioxide are risks. If you feel dizzy, nauseous, or your light source dims, the oxygen level is dropping. Stay still and find the highest point to maximize clean air.
Do not move or dig unless you are certain of the path and the stability. Use a rock or stick to tap walls and ceilings. Move along main haulage routes or passages; avoid small side passages.
Use three blasts of a whistle or three taps on a solid rock or rail track. Repeat tapping rhythmically for 30 seconds every 10 minutes. Sound travels well through rock and metal.
Condensation is often available on cave walls and ceilings. Collect it carefully. Turn off all lights immediately and rely on intermittent periods of total darkness to conserve battery.

examples: Example: Light - A small candle flame will dim noticeably when oxygen levels drop to dangerous levels.
Example: Movement - If you must travel, move slowly and drag your feet to detect sudden drop-offs or weak ground.
dos: Stay near the highest point for better air.
Conserve light and energy.
Protect the path to the entrance from further collapse.
donts: Don't yell (it wastes breath and energy).
Don't move or attempt to dig heavy debris.
Don't use fire unless absolutely necessary (consumes oxygen).

survivalGuides.title: Building a Fire Lay for Wet Wood
survivalGuides.description: How to construct a raised fire lay (platform) and use specific layouts (Log Cabin, Teepee) to dry damp wood and ensure airflow in rainy conditions.
quickSteps: 1. Create a raised platform of rocks or green logs.
2. Build the initial fire lay (Teepee) on the platform.
3. Stack damp wood vertically or nearby for drying.
4. Start the fire with concentrated, dry tinder (ID 171).

fullSteps.detail: Build a platform of flat rocks or two rows of large, fresh (green) logs. This separates the fire from cold, damp ground, which steals heat and extinguishes the flame.
In the center of the platform, build a tight Teepee lay using the driest, finest tinder and kindling (feather sticks). This concentrates the heat upward, maximizing the chances of ignition.
Stack your primary wood (small, large) nearby or above the fire on a rack. The heat rising from the fire will dry out the wood, allowing it to be used later.
Ensure maximum airflow from below and the sides. Once the fire is burning strongly, slowly introduce larger pieces of damp kindling, allowing them to steam and dry before catching fire.

examples: Example: Airflow - If the wind is low, create a small channel for air to enter the base of the fire (a natural draft).
Example: Log Cabin - Use a Log Cabin lay (square shape) once the fire is established. It is stable and burns slowly, allowing time to dry larger logs.
dos: Always build a fire on a raised, dry surface.
Protect the flame from the wind and rain (ID 171).
Feed the fire slowly and steadily.
donts: Don't use damp leaves or needles to start the fire.
Don't allow the fire to touch the wet ground.
Don't neglect to dry the next batch of wood.

survivalGuides.title: Emergency Raft Construction
survivalGuides.description: The process of quickly constructing a buoyant, stable raft from materials like logs, sealed plastic containers, or thick reeds for crossing small bodies of water.
quickSteps: 1. Gather buoyant material (dry logs, sealed barrels/jugs, reeds).
2. Choose the strongest cordage for lashing (ID 151).
3. Lash two main support logs/floatation devices (pontoons) parallel.
4. Secure cross-members for stability and a walking deck.

fullSteps.detail: Use lightweight, dry wood (cedar, pine) or, ideally, sealed plastic containers (jugs, water bottles, coolers). If using logs, choose the straightest, lightest logs that are still green (less brittle).
Lash the primary support logs/containers together using a Diagonal Lashing (ID 151) or a simple wrap-and-tie knot. The lashing must be extremely tight and non-stretching.
Attach several short, perpendicular cross-members to the main frame to maintain separation and stability. Lay smaller logs or reeds across the frame to create a dry deck.
Use a long, straight pole for pushing off the bottom (poling) in shallow water, or use a wide, flat piece of wood as a paddle. Always keep your center of gravity low.

examples: Example: Buoyancy - Use buoyant items (coolers, tires, etc.) under the raft deck to increase lift and keep the deck dry.
Example: Reed Raft - In swampy areas, bind together massive bundles of dry reeds (like thick cigars) to create a buoyant, but temporary, watercraft.
dos: Use strong, non-stretching cordage.
Build a deck wide enough to maintain balance.
Lash every joint extremely tight.
donts: Don't use heavy, water-logged materials.
Don't stand up while operating the raft.
Don't attempt to cross large, fast-moving rivers with a hastily built raft.

survivalGuides.title: The Basic Lean-To: Quick Wind/Rain Shelter
survivalGuides.description: The fastest, most basic shelter for immediate protection from rain, wind, or sun. It requires minimal materials and focuses on covering one exposed side.
quickSteps: 1. Find two trees close together or two strong vertical poles.
2. Lay a sturdy ridgepole across them (hip height).
3. Lean smaller poles (rafters) against the ridgepole at a 45-degree angle.
4. Weave or pile insulating material (boughs, leaves) onto the rafters.

fullSteps.detail: Choose a site protected from prevailing winds. Orient the lean-to so its back faces the wind or rain, and its open front faces a potential fire source.
Lash or prop a ridgepole (the main horizontal support) between two sturdy trees or upright posts, about 3 feet off the ground.
Lean numerous rafters (sticks) from the ridgepole down to the ground. The closer the rafters, the more insulation they can hold.
Shingle thick layers of pine boughs, leaves, or bark onto the frame, starting from the bottom and working up, to shed water like a roof.

examples: Example: Ridgepole - Use the Forked Stick Method if lashing is not possible: find two sticks with natural forks to support the ridgepole without cordage.
Example: Insulation - The back wall needs to be thick enough to be completely opaque when viewed from the inside.
dos: Ensure the roof slopes steeply enough to shed water.
Clear the ground of debris inside the shelter.
Build a fire directly in front of the open side for maximum heat.
donts: Don't build under dead, hanging branches.
Don't make the roof horizontal (it will collect water).
Don't forget to line the ground inside with dry insulation.

survivalGuides.title: Improvising a Tarp or Poncho Shelter
survivalGuides.description: Utilizing a poncho, plastic sheeting, or a tarp (even a simple trash bag) to create a waterproof barrier shelter. Focuses on the 'A-frame' or 'Lean-to' setup.
quickSteps: 1. Secure a ridge line (rope/paracord) between two anchor points.
2. Drape the tarp over the ridge line (A-Frame configuration).
3. Anchor the four corners firmly to the ground or nearby trees.
4. Adjust the height to minimize exposure to wind and rain.

fullSteps.detail: Run a rope between two trees, forming a ridge line. Drape the tarp over the rope, securing the edges tightly to the ground to form a tent shape. This is wind and rain resistant.
Anchor the tarp's top edge high off the ground (4-5 feet) and stake the bottom edge close to the ground. This reflects fire heat well and blocks wind on one side.
If the tarp lacks grommets, place a small, smooth rock near the edge, wrap the fabric around it, and tie cordage tightly around the neck of the wrapped rock.
Dig a small, shallow trench around the perimeter of the shelter that slopes downhill. This divers rainwater runoff away from the shelter's floor.

examples: Example: Tarp Size - A 10x10 ft tarp can comfortably shelter two people in an A-Frame setup.
Example: Improvised Tarp - Heavy-duty garbage bags slit down the side and taped together with duct tape can serve as an effective waterproof sheet.
dos: Pitch the tarp low to the ground in bad weather.
Ensure the tarp is pulled tight to prevent water collection (pockets or 'sags').
Always include a ground sheet (a second piece of plastic) to prevent heat loss to the ground.
donts: Don't use knots that will slip under tension.
Don't anchor ropes directly to rocks; anchor them to sturdy objects (trees, posts).
Don't use a tarp that is contaminated or has holes (patch them immediately).

survivalGuides.title: The A-Frame & Wickiup: Semi-Permanent Structures
survivalGuides.description: Instructions for building a robust, conical, or dome-shaped structure (Wickiup/Teepee) suitable for longer stays, maximizing interior space and stability against wind.
quickSteps: 1. Find 10-15 straight poles (rafters) 10-12 feet long.
2. Lash three main support poles together near the top to form a tripod.
3. Place the remaining poles around the tripod base to form a cone/dome.
4. Weave thin branches or cover heavily with insulating materials.

fullSteps.detail: Select three of the thickest poles and lean them together. Use cordage (or lashing techniques) to tie them securely near the top to form a strong tripod structure.
Lean the remaining poles against the tripod base, spacing them evenly to create a strong, cone-shaped frame. Leave a gap for the entrance.

Weave smaller, flexible branches (wattles) horizontally around the rafters to create a basket-like structure (Wickiup). Alternatively, cover entirely with large sheets of bark or dense boughs (Teepee/Hogan).
Leave a small opening at the very top (smoke hole) if you plan to have a small, controlled fire inside. Ensure the entrance is sealable with a flap.

examples: Example: Wickiup - Good for warm climates; the woven structure supports a lighter layer of grass/leaves for shade and bugs.
Example: Teepee - Better for cold climates; the structure is covered in a thick, dense layer of material (canvas, hides, bark) for insulation.
dos: Use strong lashings that do not slip.
The walls should be steep enough to shed rain/snow.
Choose a site with plenty of available building materials nearby.
donts: Don't build too close to large bodies of water.
Don't build a fire inside a shelter without a smoke hole and good ventilation.
Don't use poles that are rotten or brittle.

survivalGuides.title: Building an Elevated Platform (Bivouac)
survivalGuides.description: Construction of a raised sleeping platform (bivouac) to protect against cold, wet ground, insects, or minor flash floods.
quickSteps: 1. Find four strong vertical supports (forked is best).
2. Lay two parallel support logs across the supports.
3. Lay cross-members tightly together to form the bed platform.
4. Cover the platform with insulating debris.

fullSteps.detail: Choose four sturdy poles or small trees to serve as corner posts. They should be level and about 2-3 feet off the ground. If using poles, drive them into the ground firmly.
Lash or rest two long, strong logs across the vertical supports, creating the main length of the bed frame. These must bear the full weight.
Lay smaller, straight sticks or flexible saplings across the main frame, packing them tightly together to create a solid sleeping surface. Lash them to the frame.
Cover the platform generously with dry grass, leaves, or pine boughs. This is your insulation layer, separating you from the cold platform and allowing airflow underneath.

examples: Example: Tree Bivouac - Use strong, low-lying branches of a tree as the main frame supports to avoid the need for vertical posts.
Example: Swampy Areas - Essential technique for preventing hypothermia from wet ground contact.
dos: Ensure the platform is perfectly level and stable before using.
Lash all joints securely; do not rely on gravity alone.
The deck material should be smooth and knot-free.
donts: Don't build too high (risks injury if you fall).
Don't use rotten wood for the main supports.
Don't build under dead, leaning trees.

survivalGuides.title: Pit/Hole Shelter (Desert or Warm Climate)
survivalGuides.description: Utilizing the thermal mass of the earth to create a cool shelter during extreme heat or a micro-windbreak in open terrain.
quickSteps: 1. Find a spot safe from flash floods and animals.
2. Dig a hole 18-24 inches deep, long enough for your body.
3. Cover the hole with a tarp or vegetation (ground level).
4. Line the bottom with an insulating layer of fabric or grass.

fullSteps.detail: Dig a trench slightly longer and wider than your body. The depth should be about waist-high when sitting, or just deep enough for your body to be below the ambient surface air.
Pile the excavated dirt around the edge of the pit to create a low wall or berm. This improves wind protection and provides a base for the roof.
Lay branches or poles across the pit. Cover this roof heavily with a layer of the excavated dirt, leaves, or a tarp to create shade and trap the cool air inside the pit.
Orient the long axis of the pit north-south (in the Northern Hemisphere) to receive the least sun exposure, or use the dirt berm to block the prevailing afternoon sun/wind.

examples: Example: Desert - The earth 18 inches down is significantly cooler than the surface air during the day.
Example: Wind - The lip of the pit effectively blocks wind, reducing convective heat loss in cold climates (if a fire is unavailable).
dos: Use the excavated dirt to waterproof the roof.
Insulate the floor with dry material.
Ensure a clear escape path in case of rain.
donts: Don't build in a wash or low-lying area (flood risk).
Don't dig in areas with potential animal dens or nests.
Don't make the hole too small (you will lose heat to the walls).

survivalGuides.title: Snow Trench or Quinzee (Winter Shelter)
survivalGuides.description: Specialized shelter construction using snow to insulate and trap body heat, essential for survival in heavy snow and sub-freezing conditions.
quickSteps: 1. Dig a trench or pile snow into a large mound (Quinzee).
2. Wait for the snow to 'sinter' or harden (1-2 hours).
3. Hollow out the interior, leaving walls 1-2 feet thick.
4. Create a small vent hole at the top.

fullSteps.detail: Shovel or pile snow into a large mound, significantly taller and wider than the final shelter (it will compress). Stick small sticks (or 'depth gauges') through the mound's sides, about 1-2 feet long.
Wait 1-2 hours for the snow crystals to bond together (sintering). The mound will harden and become much stronger, preventing collapse during hollowing.
Crawl inside and hollow out the chamber. Stop when you hit the end of the 'depth gauge' sticks. Ensure the sleeping platform is higher than the entrance tunnel to trap warm air.
Poke a small ventilation hole (pencil-sized) through the ceiling for fresh air. Use a block of snow or a pack to seal the entrance after crawling in.

examples: Example: Snow Trench - If snow is only a few feet deep, dig a trench to ground level, cover the top with a tarp/boughs, and pile snow over the roof for insulation.
Example: Testing - Temperatures inside a well-built snow shelter can be up to $40^{\circ}\text{F}$ warmer than outside.
dos: Bring wet gear inside to dry using only body heat.
Build the sleeping platform higher than the entrance.
Dig a carbon monoxide pit (a small hole lower than the platform).
donts: Don't break the outer crust of the snow once the shelter is built.
Don't use a fire inside a snow shelter.
Don't build in an avalanche risk zone.

survivalGuides.title: The Debris Hut (Maximum Insulation)
survivalGuides.description: The ultimate simple structure for cold weather without specialized tools, designed to maximize insulation by packing massive amounts of natural debris around a small sleeping chamber.
quickSteps: 1. Build a sturdy A-frame just big enough for your body.
2. Pile two feet of dry leaves/boughs on the floor.
3. Pile two feet of debris on the roof and walls.
4. Crawl in and seal the entrance with a debris plug.

fullSteps.detail: Find a dry location. The frame should be small—just large enough for you to lay down and turn slightly. The smaller the interior, the faster your body can heat it.
Secure a ridgepole between two trees or across two strong vertical stakes. Lean numerous light rafters against the ridgepole to form the A-frame tent shape.
Layer massive amounts of dry debris (leaves, dry pine needles, grass) onto the rafters. It must be at least 2 feet thick all around, dense enough that you cannot see light through the roof.
Crucially, fill the floor with at least 6-8 inches of dry debris to insulate you from the cold ground, which drains body heat rapidly.

examples: Example: Door Plug - Use a tightly bound cylindrical bundle of debris tied together to act as a removable door that completely seals the small entrance hole once you are inside.
Example: Thermal Test - If the exterior debris is wet, the inner debris will still keep you dry and warm due to the sheer thickness of the insulation layer.
dos: Spend the time to gather enough debris (it should feel like too much).
Pack the debris down firmly.
Ensure the floor insulation is fully dry.
donts: Don't use green (live) vegetation for insulation.
Don't neglect the floor insulation.
Don't make the shelter too spacious.

survivalGuides.title: Rock Shelter/Cave Improvisation
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for utilizing natural rock overhangs, small caves, or boulders to create a sheltered micro-environment, often requiring minimal construction.
quickSteps: 1. Check the rock stability (look for cracks/loose debris).
2. Clear the floor of sharp rocks and debris.
3. Build a small, insulating wall across the open face.
4. Build a fire slightly outside the shelter, facing the wall.

fullSteps.detail: Before entering, check the ceiling and walls for loose or falling rocks. Do not choose an area that smells foul (possible den) or shows signs of immediate collapse.
Using rocks, logs, or brush, build a wall across the open entrance of the cave or overhang, leaving only a small entrance hole near the ground. This traps heat.
Build a small fire just outside the entrance. The rock wall will absorb the heat and radiate it back into the cave, or the fire will warm the air entering the small opening.
As with all shelters, heavily insulate the floor with dry leaves, grass, or pine boughs to prevent direct contact with the cold stone floor.

examples: Example: Crevice Shelter - Find a narrow rock crevice and block the windward side with stones and mud to create a micro-shelter.
Example: Desert Cave - During the day, rock shelters offer deep shade and cooler temperatures due to thermal mass.
dos: Use mud or moss to seal gaps in the entrance wall.
Keep the fire small and controlled near the entrance.
Check for water seepage before laying out the floor insulation.
donts: Don't build a fire deep inside a cave (smoke/carbon monoxide risk).
Don't rely on loose, sandy overhangs.
Don't disturb any large piles of animal droppings.

survivalGuides.title: Building a Pallet or Urban Barricade Shelter
survivalGuides.description: Utilizing discarded urban materials (pallets, plastic sheeting, cardboard) to create a temporary, defensible, and insulated shelter in an urban environment.
quickSteps: 1. Secure four pallets/frames for the walls (vertical).
2. Lash the corners together for stability.
3. Drape plastic sheeting or tarp over the roof for waterproofing.
4. Line the inside with cardboard for maximum insulation.

fullSteps.detail: Use wooden pallets, crates, or sturdy furniture pieces to form the four walls. The pallet structure naturally provides an air gap for insulation.
Use nails, screws, duct tape, or cordage (wire is best) to lash the four corners securely. The structure must be able to withstand moderate wind.
Use thin boards or a piece of plywood for the roof, covered with plastic sheeting or garbage bags to create a waterproof layer. Overlap the layers to shed water.
Cardboard is an excellent urban insulator. Place layers of cardboard on the floor and tape it to the interior walls to create dead air space and conserve heat.

examples: Example: Defense - Face the entrance toward a cleared area, and use additional pallets/debris to create an outer defensive barrier (barricade).
Example: Heat Source - A few tea candles placed in a metal can can safely raise the interior temperature several degrees in a small, sealed shelter.
dos: Always build on level ground.
Check pallets for toxic spills or heavy contamination before use.
Ensure all openings are sealed against wind and moisture.
donts: Don't use fire inside the structure (pallets/cardboard are extremely flammable).
Don't build near unstable structures or power lines.
Don't use rotten or severely damaged materials.

survivalGuides.title: Securing an Improvised Door/Entrance
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for creating a functional, secure, and easily-operated entrance flap or door that retains heat/excludes predators, insects, and weather.
quickSteps: 1. Make the entrance small (just large enough to crawl through).
2. Cut or create a door flap from durable material (tarp, hide, woven boughs).
3. Attach the flap securely at the top (hinge).
4. Use weighted objects or simple latches to seal the bottom.

fullSteps.detail: The entrance should be minimal in size to prevent heat loss. In cold weather, orient the entrance away from the prevailing wind.
Use a piece of heavy fabric, plastic, woven mats, or a dense bundle of pine boughs for the door flap. It must be slightly larger than the opening to overlap the edges.
Attach the top of the flap securely to the shelter's frame (ridgepole, branch, or door frame) using lashing or nails, allowing it to swing or hang freely.
Use rocks, heavy logs, or packed snow/dirt around the base of the flap to seal it when closed. Alternatively, use a rope and stick latch on the inside to secure it against wind.

examples: Example: Debris Hut - Use a tightly bound cylindrical bundle of debris as a plug that fits snugly into the entrance hole.
Example: Woven Mat - Weave grass or reeds tightly together to form a lightweight, insulating door that can be rolled up or tied down.
dos: Ensure the door opens and closes silently.
The flap should seal tightly on all sides to prevent drafts.
Test the mechanism before dark.
donts: Don't make the entrance too high (allows warm air to escape).
Don't use a highly reflective or noisy material for the door.
Don't rely on a door that is only secured from the outside.

survivalGuides.title: Making Flour from Wild Grass Seeds (Winnowing)
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for harvesting and processing tiny wild grass seeds (like foxtail or wild rice) into a coarse, edible flour or meal.
quickSteps: 1. Collect seed heads by stripping or shaking them into a container.
2. Toast the seeds lightly over a low fire to make the husks brittle.
3. Crush the seeds/husks (pestle/rock) into a coarse mixture.
4. Winnow (toss in the air) to let the chaff blow away, leaving the meal behind.

fullSteps.detail: Identify grass with large, abundant seed heads. Harvest by rubbing the seed heads between your hands over a container, or by cutting the entire head off.
Spread the collected seeds on a flat rock near a fire or in a metal pan. Toasting them lightly improves flavor and makes the husk (chaff) easier to remove.
Use a smooth, hard rock (pestle) against a flat, stable rock (mortar) to grind the parched seeds into a meal or flour. Grind until the desired consistency is reached.
On a windy day, pour the ground mixture slowly from one container to another, allowing the lighter chaff to be carried away by the wind, leaving the heavier meal.

examples: Example: Wild Rice - An excellent source of starch, often found in shallow lakes and marshes. It is harvested by bending the stalks over a canoe/boat.
Example: Grinding - A hollowed-out log or stump can be used as a large mortar if large rocks are unavailable.
dos: Only harvest seeds that are dry and easily fall off the stalk.
Keep the seed collection clean to minimize dirt/sand.
Store the resulting meal in a completely dry, airtight container.
donts: Don't eat moldy or wet seeds/meal.
Don't grind on granite or porous rock (gritty meal).
Don't confuse grass seeds with toxic grains.

survivalGuides.title: Creating an Improvised Bee Smoker/Honey Harvest
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for safely accessing and harvesting wild honey (high-calorie food) by creating a smoker to pacify the bees.
quickSteps: 1. Locate a wild beehive (usually in a tree hollow or rock crevice).
2. Build a small, smoky fire with rotten wood or damp leaves.
3. Use a hollow tube or bellows to direct the smoke toward the hive entrance.
4. Carefully cut out the combs containing honey (not the larvae/brood).

fullSteps.detail: Watch bee flight patterns to trace them back to their nest. Note the entrance and plan an escape route.
Create a smoke source using damp leaves, moss, or punkwood (rotten wood). The goal is thick, cool smoke, not flame. Direct the smoke using a fan or a hollow reed/bamboo stick.
Send smoke directly into the hive entrance. Smoke suppresses the bees' alarm pheromone and encourages them to gorge on honey (making them docile).
Using gloves or thick wrapping (if available), quickly cut out only the combs containing liquid honey. Leave some honey and the brood (larvae) to ensure the colony survives.

examples: Example: Protection - Wear long sleeves, pants, and cover your face with a piece of netting/cloth if possible, as bee stings can be serious.
Example: Larvae - Bee larvae (grubs) are also high in protein and edible after cooking, but should be left in the nest if colony survival is the priority.
dos: Move slowly and deliberately; avoid sudden movements.
Always leave enough resources for the bees to survive.
Use cool smoke; do not set the hive on fire.
donts: Don't attempt this if you have a known allergy to bee venom.
Don't harvest during peak midday activity.
Don't destroy the entire hive for a single harvest.

survivalGuides.title: Identifying and Preparing Edible Freshwater Clams/Mussels
survivalGuides.description: Locating filter feeders (clams, mussels) in clean freshwater sources and the crucial safety steps required for preparing them.
quickSteps: 1. Find a source of clean, non-stagnant freshwater.
2. Look for trails/marks in the mud or sand near the shore.
3. Harvest only live, tightly closed shells.
4. **Crucial:** Boil or steam them for a minimum of 10 minutes.

fullSteps.detail: Only harvest from extremely clean, clear water. Clams and mussels filter water and can concentrate toxins (e.g., from algae bloom or runoff) in polluted areas.
If the shell is open, tap it. If it doesn't quickly clamp shut, discard it (it is dead). You should feel resistance when prying the shell open.
Place the live clams/mussels in a bucket of clean water with a bit of meal/corn flour for 12 hours. This encourages them to filter out sand and grit.
Boil or steam until the shells are fully open. **Discard any shellfish that do not open** after cooking, as this indicates they were dead or contaminated.

examples: Example: Cooking - Steaming preserves more flavor than boiling; place them on hot rocks near a fire and cover with wet leaves.
Example: Spoilage - Shellfish spoil very quickly. They must be consumed or fully processed (smoked/dried) immediately after harvest.
dos: Cook immediately after harvest.
Check for signs of pollution (dead fish, strong odors) before harvesting.
Ensure the water source is free of industrial or agricultural runoff.
donts: Don't eat raw freshwater shellfish (high parasite risk).
Don't eat any shellfish that remains closed after cooking.
Don't harvest from stagnant ponds or lakes.

survivalGuides.title: Cooking Fish and Game Without Utensils (Hot Rocks/Clay)
survivalGuides.description: Primitive cooking methods using natural elements like heated stones (stone boiling) or wrapping food in clay/leaves and placing it in coals.
quickSteps: 1. Find non-porous river rocks (no layered sandstone/granite).
2. Heat the rocks in a fire until they glow red-hot.
3. **For Fish/Game:** Wrap the food in thick mud or clay and place it in the coals.
4. **For Boiling:** Drop the hot stones into a water-filled container (basket, hide, wooden bowl) until the water boils.

fullSteps.detail: Gut the animal/fish but leave the skin/scales. Cover the entire carcass in a thick, 1-inch layer of wet clay or mud. Place it in the hot coals and bury it slightly. When the clay is rock-hard, crack it open; the skin/scales should peel off with the clay.

Place clean, non-porous rocks (river stones are ideal) directly onto the fire. Once red-hot, remove them, wipe them clean, and place them in a pit. Place the meat/fish directly on the hot rocks and cover with a lid/dirt to seal in heat.

Skewer the meat or fish along the spine with a long, straight stick (spit). Prop the spit over the fire on two forked sticks, ensuring the food is near the coals but not touching the flame. Rotate frequently.

examples: Example: Rock Choice - Avoid quartz, layered shale, or porous river rocks, which can explode when heated due to trapped moisture.
Example: Stone Boiling - If a metal pot is unavailable, a tightly woven basket or a leather pouch can be used to hold water for boiling if the hot rocks are dropped inside.
dos: Use wood coals, not high flames, for slow, even cooking.
Ensure the interior temperature reaches a safe level to kill parasites.
Use green wood for the spit or skewers.
donts: Don't cook meat directly on smoky/sooty wood (bitter taste).
Don't use river rocks directly from the water for heating.
Don't eat raw or undercooked wild game.

survivalGuides.title: Making and Storing Pemmican (High-Calorie Travel Food)
survivalGuides.description: A traditional, extremely calorie-dense and shelf-stable survival food made from lean, dried meat, rendered fat (tallow), and optional berries.
quickSteps: 1. Dry very lean meat (jerky) until brittle and powder it.
2. Render animal fat into pure, liquid tallow.
3. Mix the meat powder and tallow (2:1 fat to meat ratio).
4. Press the mixture into blocks and store in a cool, dry place.

fullSteps.detail: Sun-dry or smoke strips of lean meat until they are completely brittle. Use a mortar and pestle or two rocks to grind the jerky into a fine, dust-like powder.
Melt the rendered tallow gently over low heat. Mix in the meat powder until the fat completely absorbs it. The consistency should be thick and moldable.
Mix in small amounts of dried berries (e.g., cranberries, blueberries) or ground nuts for flavor and vitamins.
Press the pemmican mixture tightly into small logs or squares. Wrap tightly in cloth, wax paper, or plastic. Pemmican can last years if stored in a cool, dry, dark environment.

examples: Example: Ratio - The classic ratio is 50% dried meat, 40% rendered fat, and 10% dried berries or nuts.
Example: Calorie Density - A small block of pemmican provides a concentrated energy source ideal for travel or cold weather.
dos: Use only fully rendered, pure fat (no bits of meat).
Ensure the meat is completely dried before mixing.
Use lean meat only.
donts: Don't use unrendered fat (it will spoil quickly).
Don't use sugar (it reduces shelf life).
Don't introduce moisture during storage.

survivalGuides.title: Finding and Utilizing Bird Eggs (Safety and Season)
survivalGuides.description: Locating edible bird and reptile eggs during nesting seasons and how to determine if an egg is fresh enough to eat.
quickSteps: 1. Focus efforts during spring/early summer (nesting season).
2. Look for nests in low brush, hollow logs, or near water (waterfowl).
3. **Test Freshness:** Shake the egg; if it sloshes or moves, it is likely spoiled or near hatching.
4. Boil or roast all wild eggs before consumption.

fullSteps.detail: Watch for secretive bird activity, especially repetitive trips to a specific location. Waterfowl nests (ducks, geese) are often easily found near the shoreline or reeds.
Place the egg in water. A fresh egg sinks to the bottom. An older egg stands on its end. A spoiled egg will float completely.
Never take all the eggs from a nest. Only take one or two, ensuring the bird will continue to sit on the rest and the clutch will survive.
Cook eggs immediately (boiling is safest) to kill bacteria. Even if slightly spoiled, cooking can render them edible in a survival scenario, though taste will suffer.

examples: Example: Sea Birds - On coastal areas, gull and murre eggs are highly abundant during nesting season but require careful identification.
Example: Reptile Eggs - Turtle eggs are sometimes found in sandy areas near water; they must be boiled or baked.
dos: Always cook wild eggs to reduce the risk of salmonella.
Harvest sustainably (leave most eggs in the nest).
Collect eggs in the early morning before the birds return.
donts: Don't eat eggs if they have a foul odor or are severely cracked.
Don't touch the nest structure or surrounding vegetation unnecessarily.
Don't eat eggs if they have a discernible embryo inside.

survivalGuides.title: Fishing with Netting or Traps (Gill Nets/Funnel Traps)
survivalGuides.description: Setting up passive fishing gear like simple gill nets (if mesh/cordage is available) or funnel traps made of woven reeds/sticks in streams and ponds.
quickSteps: 1. Construct a funnel-shaped basket trap (wider entrance, narrow exit).
2. Place bait (worms, insects) inside the narrow end.
3. Position the trap in a stream or pond where fish swim along the bank.
4. Check the trap frequently and reposition if unsuccessful.

fullSteps.detail: Weave thin, flexible branches into a cylinder. Weave a second piece into a cone shape, attach it inside the cylinder, and make sure the cone's point is facing inward to create a one-way entrance.

If netting is available, stretch the net across a narrow part of a waterway or in a lake, anchoring the top to a float (log) and the bottom to weights (rocks). The net should be set perpendicular to the fish's travel path.
Bait for traps should be strong-smelling—crushed snails, fat, or fish guts work best to attract scavenging fish.
Remove fish from nets/traps immediately to prevent them from attracting predators or spoiling. Be aware of local laws regarding fishing nets.

examples: Example: Small Streams - Build two stone walls that converge into a small opening. Place the funnel trap in the opening to concentrate the flow of fish.
Example: Trap Weight - Use heavy stones inside the funnel trap to keep it stationary in a current.
dos: Build multiple traps to increase the odds of success.
Place traps near cover (logs, rocks) where fish hide.
Check traps at dawn and dusk.
donts: Don't leave traps unattended for days.
Don't use nets that are visible to the fish.
Don't build traps in areas with strong, destructive currents.

survivalGuides.title: Using Fire to Harden Wooden Tools and Weapon Tips
survivalGuides.description: Technique for using fire to strengthen and sharpen the tips of wooden spears, digging sticks, or fire plow pieces.
quickSteps: 1. Sharpen the wooden tip to a fine point.
2. Hold the tip just above the hot, red coals (not in the flame).
3. Rotate the tip constantly and slowly until the wood turns black and starts to sweat (char).
4. Scrape off the char, then repeat the process until the wood is dark brown and very hard.

fullSteps.detail: Using a knife or sharp stone, carve the end of the wooden tool (spear, shovel, digging stick) into the desired shape—a fine point for stabbing, a flat edge for digging.
Hold the tip in the hottest part of the heat (over the white-hot coals). The temperature must be high enough to break down the surface cellulose but not so high as to cause it to burn.

The charred layer must be scraped off immediately (using a knife or sharp rock). This exposes the next layer. Repeat the process 3-5 times. The repeated heating and scraping seals the fibers, creating a much harder, durable tip.

examples: Example: Digging Stick - A fire-hardened tip will last much longer when breaking up hard, rocky soil to find tubers or roots.
Example: Spear - A hardened tip can penetrate thick hides more effectively than green, unhardened wood.
dos: Use green (freshly cut) hardwood for best results.
Work slowly and rotate constantly to prevent splitting.
Finish with a final polish using a piece of smooth leather or rock.
donts: Don't put the wood directly in the flame (it will burn the tip off).
Don't use rotten or dried-out wood (it will crumble).
Don't let the wood burn past the surface level.

survivalGuides.title: Milking and Utilizing Tree Sap (Maple/Birch Tapping)
survivalGuides.description: Tapping certain trees (e.g., Maple, Birch) during late winter/early spring to collect sugar-water sap for hydration and emergency caloric intake.
quickSteps: 1. Identify a suitable tree (Maple, Birch, Sycamore).
2. Drill or chop a small hole (1/2 inch deep) at a slight upward angle.
3. Insert a piece of reed or hollow tube (spile) into the hole.
4. Place a container (cup, bark scroll) beneath the spile to collect the dripping sap.

fullSteps.detail: Sap runs best in late winter/early spring when temperatures are below freezing at night and above freezing during the day. Identify Sugar Maple, Red Maple, or Birch trees.
Use a drill or sharp tool to bore a hole about 1/2 to 1 inch into the trunk, 2 to 4 feet above the ground. Angle the hole slightly upward to encourage flow.
Find a stiff, hollow reed or use a section of elderberry (which has a soft pith that can be pushed out) as a makeshift spout (spile). Gently tap it into the hole.
Place a bark container, cup, or even a wide leaf beneath the spile to catch the dripping sap. The sap is clear, slightly sweet water and can be consumed as is, or boiled down for syrup.

examples: Example: Birch Sap - Can be tapped earlier than maple and is less sweet, but still a source of minerals.
Example: Spile - A hollow piece of bamboo, cane, or metal tubing (if available) works best.
dos: Boil the sap if there is any doubt about water quality.
Only tap mature, healthy trees (12 inches diameter minimum).
Plug the hole with a stick or mud after harvesting to aid the tree's healing.
donts: Don't tap the same spot on a tree repeatedly.
Don't tap toxic trees (e.g., Cherry, Oak).
Don't over-harvest, as the tree needs sap to grow.

survivalGuides.title: Making and Setting a Spring Snare (Neck Break)
survivalGuides.description: An advanced, high-tension snare that uses a bent sapling (spring pole) to quickly hoist and dispatch small game, ensuring a clean kill.
quickSteps: 1. Find a strong, flexible sapling and bend it to the ground.
2. Set up a simple trigger system (e.g., figure-four) to anchor the bent sapling.
3. Place a small wire/cord loop (snare) where the animal will step.
4. When the animal steps on the trigger, the sapling springs up, hoisting the animal.

fullSteps.detail: Select a live, flexible sapling or limb with enough tension to lift the target animal. Securely anchor a strong line (cordage) to the sapling's tip.
Carve a trigger stick or use a notched toggle stick that anchors the bent sapling to the ground via a ground stake. The anchor must release easily when moved.
Attach the snare loop (wire or thin cordage) to the trigger mechanism. The loop must be placed directly over a game trail or feeding spot.
Carefully camouflage the trigger and anchor points with leaves, dirt, and light brush. Do not cover the snare loop itself.

examples: Example: Tension - The sapling must be bent far enough to ensure a powerful, quick upward snap, which is crucial for a humane and clean kill.
Example: Trigger - The 'twitch-up' or 'toggle-pin' trigger is the simplest mechanism for anchoring the tension.
dos: Set multiple snares along known game trails for higher success.
Check all traps at least twice a day.
Anchor the main line to the base of the sapling as a safety backup.
donts: Don't build in a way that risks accidental discharge on humans.
Don't use a spring pole that is too weak to lift the animal.
Don't build near domestic animals.

survivalGuides.title: Hunting with Decoys and Calls (Small Game/Waterfowl)
survivalGuides.description: Using simple auditory calls or visual attractants (decoys) to draw animals closer to a hunting or trapping location.
quickSteps: 1. Study common bird/game calls (e.g., owl, rabbit distress).
2. Use natural materials (bark, reeds) to create a simple whistle or call.
3. Create a crude decoy (carved wood, mud) of a common bird or mammal.
4. Use the call/decoy near a concealed ambush point.

fullSteps.detail: Decide on a common local target (e.g., duck, crow, squirrel, rabbit). This dictates the required call and decoy design.

For birds, a simple whistle using folded leaves or a hollow piece of cane can imitate many bird calls. For rabbits, imitate the distress squeal by blowing over a blade of grass stretched between your thumbs.
Carve a crude wooden decoy or use feathers and mud to create a shape of a common bird. Place the decoy where it is visible to passing game, preferably in a calm area of water (for waterfowl).
Wait downwind in a natural or improvised blind (ID 278). Use the call sparingly to avoid alerting the game; let the visual decoy and the animal's natural curiosity do most of the work.

examples: Example: Crow - Crows are attracted by visual decoys and the call of an injured crow or owl hooting.
Example: Squirrel - A simple scratch of leaves can mimic a foraging squirrel, drawing in nearby competition.
dos: Use calls and decoys early in the morning or late in the evening.
Practice calls until they sound natural and not panicked.
Ensure the decoy is stabilized against wind/current.
donts: Don't overuse calls (it can scare the animal away).
Don't use calls on days with no wind (sound travels too far).
Don't rely on calls alone; combine with a natural funnel or blind.

survivalGuides.title: Creating an Emergency Food Calendar
survivalGuides.description: Mapping out the seasonal availability of wild plants, game, and water sources in a local area to maximize foraging and hunting efficiency.
quickSteps: 1. Divide the year into four seasons.
2. Research or observe which plants/animals are abundant in each season.
3. Note when berries ripen, when sap runs, and when fish spawn.
4. Use this calendar to prioritize foraging efforts and movement.

fullSteps.detail: Note which edible plants (e.g., dandelion, clover, cattail) emerge first in spring. Track the flowering, fruiting, and seeding times throughout the year.
Observe and record when different game animals (deer, rabbit, squirrel) are most active, when birds nest, and when fish spawn or move to feeding areas.
Use a piece of paper, bark, or mud to create a simple chart. List the 10 most reliable food sources and mark the months they are available, focusing on caloric and nutritional value.
Use the chart to plan sustainable harvesting. For example, harvest berries only when they are peaking, then switch to root crops, then to hunting in the fall.

examples: Example: Spring - Abundant greens (dandelion, fiddlehead), tree sap, and bird eggs.
Example: Fall - Dominant source is nuts (acorns, hickory) and dried fruit (rose hips), with increased animal fat reserves.
dos: Focus on 3-5 high-yield food sources per season.
Prioritize calorie sources (fats and starches) over vitamins (greens).
Update the calendar with new observations annually.
donts: Don't rely on memory; keep a physical record.
Don't harvest a single resource to the point of extinction in your area.
Don't rely on migratory animals if you cannot track them.

survivalGuides.title: Identifying and Avoiding Scavenger/Sick Animals
survivalGuides.description: Recognizing signs of disease (rabies, tuberculosis, parasitic infections) in game animals, which can be transferred to humans.
quickSteps: 1. Never consume an animal found dead (scavenger risk).
2. Look for obvious signs of sickness: lethargy, unusual aggression, hair loss, lesions.
3. Check the internal organs (liver/lungs) for spots or cysts.
4. If in doubt, **do not consume** the animal.

fullSteps.detail: A healthy animal flees quickly. Look for animals that appear disoriented, lethargic, or unnaturally aggressive/tame. These are red flags for neurological diseases like rabies.
After a kill, inspect the hide for tumors, large abscesses, missing patches of hair (mange), or abnormal discharges. Look for signs of ticks or heavy flea infestation.
The liver and lungs are key indicators. A healthy liver is smooth and uniform. Look for white spots or growths (tuberculosis, tapeworm cysts). If the liver is covered in spots, discard the carcass.
Meat should be uniform in color. Look for green or yellowish streaks or fluid, which indicate infection. Cook meat thoroughly, especially pork and bear (trichinosis).

examples: Example: Rabbit - If a rabbit is slow to flee, check the liver for white spots (Tularemia). If found, the animal is unusable.
Example: Bear - Bear and wild pig meat must be cooked to $160^{\circ}\text{F}$ to kill trichinosis parasites.
dos: Wear gloves or cover hands with plastic/leaves when field dressing a suspect animal.
Always cook meat to well-done.
Clean all tools thoroughly after processing a suspect animal.
donts: Don't eat the organs of an animal that appeared sick.
Don't process a sick animal near a water source.
Don't assume a parasite is harmless.

survivalGuides.title: Collecting and Preparing Wild Edible Seeds/Nuts
survivalGuides.description: Foraging for high-calorie, storable nuts and seeds (e.g., hickory, walnut, sunflower) and the techniques needed to process them.
quickSteps: 1. Identify trees by their leaves and bark.
2. Crack the nut (rock/stone) and check for mold or insects.
3. **Almond Rule:** Avoid nuts/seeds that smell like bitter almonds (cyanide risk).
4. Roast nuts to improve flavor and digestibility.

fullSteps.detail: Focus on gathering nuts immediately after they fall from the tree, ideally before squirrels or other rodents can gather them. Collect nuts with the husks still on to protect the shell.
Remove the outer husk (e.g., walnut, hickory). Crack the hard shell using a heavy rock. The nut meat should be uniform in color and firm.
Always check for excessive bitterness. Bitter nuts (like certain acorns or chestnuts) require leaching (ID 226). Sweet nuts (pecan, hazelnut) can be eaten or roasted immediately.
Dry the nut meats completely (in the sun or near a fire). Store them in their shells or sealed containers to prevent spoilage and insect infestation.

examples: Example: Hickory - Use a heavy rock to crack the incredibly hard shell; the meat is rich in oil and calories.
Example: Sunflower - The seeds are edible raw or roasted; they require drying to prevent mildew if stored.
dos: Soak extremely hard-shelled nuts (like black walnuts) in water for an hour before cracking.
Roast nuts lightly over a fire to improve flavor and increase shelf life.
Use nuts to press oil (cooking fat) if processing large quantities.
donts: Don't eat nuts with a fuzzy coating or evidence of mold.
Don't store nuts that still have moisture on them.
Don't rely on nuts as your only caloric source (fatigue).

survivalGuides.title: Emergency Detoxification of Water Plants (Cattail/Lotus)
survivalGuides.description: Cleaning, leaching, or cooking certain water-based plants (which can absorb contaminants) to ensure they are safe for consumption.
quickSteps: 1. Harvest water plants only from clean, moving water.
2. Peel the outer layer of stems/roots.
3. Dice the plant and soak it in clean water for 30 minutes.
4. Boil the plant in a new batch of clean water, discarding the cooking water.

fullSteps.detail: Cattails, water lilies, and reeds absorb pollutants. Only harvest from areas with clear, running water that is known to be free of industrial or agricultural runoff.

Peel away the tough outer layers of the stem or root (rhizome). Chop the edible white/inner parts into small pieces. Soak the pieces in a clean container of water for at least 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Boil the plant pieces in clean water for 10-15 minutes. Discard the cooking water, as it will contain concentrated tannins and potential toxins. This step is critical for plants like Bracken Fern.
The cooked pieces can now be eaten. The process removes bitterness and neutralizes some minor toxins that are water-soluble.

examples: Example: Cattail - The white inner root is highly starchy. It is safe to eat cooked, but may contain water-borne contaminants if the water source is poor.
Example: Water Hemlock - Looks similar to safe water plants. **Crucially, never eat a wild root that smells like parsley or a parsnip** unless you are 100% certain of its identity.
dos: Cook all water-based roots and stems thoroughly.
Discard the water used for boiling/soaking.
Use caution when harvesting from fast-moving rivers (slipping risk).
donts: Don't consume the seed heads of cattails (unless fully ripened and processed).
Don't harvest plants showing signs of mold or discoloration.
Don't eat aquatic plants raw.

survivalGuides.title: Using Fire to Preserve Meat (Jerky Making)
survivalGuides.description: The process of slicing meat thinly and using a low, smoldering fire and airflow to dehydrate and cure it for indefinite storage.
quickSteps: 1. Slice lean meat into 1/4-inch thin strips (grain-running).
2. Hang the strips from a rack or pole over a low, smoldering (smoking) fire.
3. Maintain heat (95°F to 120°F) and airflow for 12-24 hours.
4. The jerky is done when it bends but does not break.

fullSteps.detail: Use only lean meat (remove all visible fat, which spoils quickly). Slice the meat thinly (1/4 inch) with the grain to ensure it retains its shape during drying.
If salt is available, rub the strips generously. This draws out moisture and kills surface bacteria, greatly improving preservation.
Build a frame or rack 4-6 feet above a small, smokey fire (low temperature). The fire should not flame up or cook the meat; it should only generate low heat and thick smoke.
Hang the strips, ensuring they don't touch. Turn them every few hours. The process is complete when the jerky is dark, firm, and you can bend it without it snapping.

examples: Example: Smoked Flavor - Use fruit woods (apple, cherry) or hardwoods (hickory, oak) for the fire to impart a desirable flavor.
Example: Sun Drying - In very hot, dry climates, jerky can be made by simply hanging it in direct sun, covered with mesh to deter insects.
dos: Remove all fat before drying.
Ensure good airflow around all sides of the strips.
Store finished jerky in a breathable bag (cloth) in a dry place.
donts: Don't use green, sappy wood for the fire (bad taste).
Don't let the fire get too hot (it will cook the meat).
Don't store jerky until it is completely dry.

survivalGuides.title: Improvised Hunting Blind or Ambush Point
survivalGuides.description: Building a concealed structure (blind) near a water source or game trail to wait for game without being detected.
quickSteps: 1. Identify a strategic point (near a trail or water/food source).
2. Ensure the wind is blowing from the game toward you (downwind).
3. Use local vegetation (boughs, leaves) to build a small, opaque wall.
4. Remain still and silent while waiting for game.

fullSteps.detail: Locate an active game trail or a feeding area (e.g., acorn drop, salt lick). Determine the prevailing wind direction and build the blind so the wind carries your scent away from the animals (always stay downwind).
Use three or four sturdy sticks driven into the ground to create a small, three-sided enclosure. The size should be just large enough to sit or crouch comfortably.
Weave branches and pile pine boughs, grass, or leaves onto the frame. The wall must be completely opaque (you should not be able to see through it). Leave small viewing holes.
Camo the top and edges of the blind to blend with the natural background. Clear the ground inside the blind of all dry leaves/twigs to prevent making noise when shifting position.

examples: Example: Waterfowl - Use reeds, tall grass, and mud to construct a low-lying blind near the edge of a pond or marsh.
Example: Deer - Build a blind near the edge of a thicket facing an open clearing where deer feed at dawn/dusk.
dos: Set the blind up several hours or a day before hunting (let the area cool down).
Use enough material to break up your outline completely.
Clear a clear shooting lane from the blind.
donts: Don't smoke or build a fire nearby.
Don't stand up or move unnecessarily.
Don't build directly on the game trail itself.

survivalGuides.title: Identifying and Utilizing Tree Buds and Catkins
survivalGuides.description: Foraging for the vitamin and mineral-rich emerging buds and catkins (flowers) of certain trees (e.g., Willow, Aspen, Birch) in early spring.
quickSteps: 1. Harvest only from non-toxic trees (Birch, Aspen, Willow).
2. Collect the buds just as they are swelling or the catkins when young.
3. Eat small quantities raw, or boil the buds to reduce bitterness.
4. The buds and catkins are a vital early-season source of nutrients.

fullSteps.detail: Tree buds are best in early spring just before they leaf out, when they contain the highest concentration of stored energy. Catkins (the flower clusters) are generally edible when young and tender.
Pinch the buds directly off the branch tips. Only harvest a few buds per branch, ensuring the tree's overall health and ability to produce leaves is not compromised.
Some buds (like Poplar) are quite bitter due to high resin content. Boiling the buds briefly in water, then discarding the water, can significantly improve the taste.
Buds are often eaten raw for their vitamin C content. Catkins (from birch or willow) can be added to stews or ground into a nutrient-rich flour.

examples: Example: Poplar - The sticky, resinous coating on the buds can be used as a medicinal ointment; the inner bud is edible after boiling.
Example: Birch - The young catkins (male flowers) are edible raw and have a slightly piney flavor.
dos: Only take buds from lower branches of tall trees.
Always confirm the tree species before consumption.
Use buds as a source of vitamin C (anti-scurvy).
donts: Don't strip a tree of all its buds.
Don't eat toxic tree buds (e.g., Buckeye, Horse Chestnut).
Don't eat old, dried-out catkins.

survivalGuides.title: Water-Proofing Food Storage (Pitch Sealing)
survivalGuides.description: Using rendered tree resin (pitch) to waterproof leather, wooden containers, or lids, protecting stored food (e.g., pemmican, grain) from moisture and pests.
quickSteps: 1. Collect pine or spruce resin/sap (pitch).
2. Heat the pitch gently until it is fully liquid (do not boil).
3. Brush or pour the liquid pitch over the container seams/lids.
4. Allow the pitch to cool and harden fully before storing food.

fullSteps.detail: Look for hardened globs of amber-colored resin leaking from pine, spruce, or fir trees (the pitch). Scrape it off using a knife or sharp stick.
Melt the pitch slowly in a container over low heat. For extra flexibility and durability, mix in a handful of crushed charcoal or fine ash, and a small amount of animal fat (tallow).
While the pitch mixture is warm and liquid, brush or pour it over the seams and gaps of a wooden box, bark container, or clay pot. Ensure a thick, complete coating.
Allow the pitch to cool and harden completely. The resulting seal is waterproof, airtight, and deters most pests. It can be used to seal dried food (pemmican, grains) for caching.

examples: Example: Pitch Glue - The pitch mixture is an excellent all-purpose adhesive for making tools, attaching arrowheads, and patching containers.
Example: Canvas/Cloth - Pitch can be rubbed into dense cloth (canvas or burlap) to create a waterproof material for wrapping food or gear.
dos: Use a low, steady heat for rendering pitch (it is flammable).
Mix the pitch well with fat/ash for a flexible, less brittle sealant.
Apply the pitch to dry surfaces only.
donts: Don't use pitch from toxic trees (e.g., Box Elder, Black Locust).
Don't apply pitch to hot materials (it will run off).
Don't touch the liquid pitch (it burns and is difficult to remove).

survivalGuides.title: Sustaining a Long-Term Garden (Pest Control)
survivalGuides.description: Non-chemical, survival methods for controlling common garden pests (insects, rodents) and disease to ensure crop viability.
quickSteps: 1. Plant strong-smelling herbs (onions, mint) as 'companion plants'.
2. Physically remove pests (squash bugs, caterpillars) by hand.
3. Use ash or crushed eggshells as a barrier against slugs/snails.
4. Use a cage or barrier (sticks, netting) to deter larger animals.

fullSteps.detail: Inspect plants daily. Hand-pick large insects (caterpillars, tomato hornworms) and drop them into a jar of soapy water or crush them. Use nets or cheesecloth over plants to deter flying insects.
Plant strongly aromatic species (onions, garlic, marigolds, nasturtiums) near vulnerable crops. These 'companion plants' repel common pests like squash bugs and aphids.
For slugs and snails, create a ring of sharp or irritating material (crushed eggshells, wood ash, sand) around the base of the plant to prevent them from crossing.
Build small barriers or fences using woven sticks or salvaged wire mesh to protect rows from rabbits, squirrels, and deer. Place noisemakers (cans, bells) on stakes.

examples: Example: Aphids - A strong blast of water or a spray made from diluted soap and ash can wash off and kill aphids.
Example: Cabbage Moth - Cover cabbage/broccoli with a thin netting or row cover to prevent the moth from laying eggs.
dos: Practice crop rotation to confuse pests (don't plant the same crop in the same spot).
Encourage beneficial insects (ladybugs, praying mantis).
Weed regularly to reduce insect hiding spots.
donts: Don't use chemicals that contaminate the food.
Don't leave dead or diseased plant material in the garden.
Don't water the plants from above (increases risk of fungal disease).

survivalGuides.title: Leached Acorn Flour Patties (The Staple)
survivalGuides.description: Making starchy, high-calorie flour from bitter acorns by leaching out the inedible tannins, then cooking the flour into patties.
quickSteps: 1. Shell, chop, and grind acorns into a coarse meal.
2. Place the meal in a cloth/mesh bag and submerge it in running water (stream).
3. Leaching is done when the meal tastes neutral (no bitterness).
4. Mix with water to form patties and bake on a hot rock.

fullSteps.detail: Grind the shelled acorns into a fine powder. Taste a small amount; if it's bitter, it must be leached. If it's sweet (e.g., some White Oaks), leaching is optional.
Place the meal in a woven bag or cloth and submerge it in a stream or river current. The running water carries the tannins away. This takes 4–24 hours, depending on the flow.
Once leached and dried slightly, mix the wet meal with a small amount of water to form a sticky dough. Flatten into thin patties (1/4 inch thick).
Bake the patties on a hot, flat rock near the coals or dry-fry them in a pan/flat piece of bark until firm and dry.

examples: Example: Hot Water Leaching - Boiling the flour and discarding the brown water multiple times is faster but removes more nutrients.
Example: Storage - Acorn meal spoils quickly; it must be cooked immediately or completely dried and stored in an airtight container.
dos: Leach until all bitterness is gone.
Use fine-ground meal for faster leaching.
Store the finished patties in a dry, cool place.
donts: Don't consume unleached (bitter) acorns.
Don't let the raw meal sit wet after leaching (it molds fast).
Don't mistake the outer cap for the shell (the shell must be removed).

survivalGuides.title: Universal Bone Broth (Maximum Nutrient Extraction)
survivalGuides.description: A liquid meal rich in minerals, gelatin, and hydration, made from simmering the bones and connective tissues of any harvested game.
quickSteps: 1. Collect bones, skin, and joints of harvested game.
2. Crush the largest bones (rock) to expose marrow.
3. Cover with water in a container.
4. Simmer over low heat for 4–24 hours; drink the resulting liquid.

fullSteps.detail: Collect all available bones, especially joints (kneecaps, knuckles), which are rich in collagen. For large bones, smash them with a heavy rock to access the marrow.
Place the bones in a pot (or stone-boiling vessel) and cover them with clean water. Add any available edible wild roots (e.g., wild onion, cattail) for flavor and nutrients.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to a bare simmer. Cook for a minimum of 4 hours, and up to 24 hours, to fully dissolve the connective tissue and minerals.
Strain the liquid and drink it warm. This broth is excellent for rehydration and providing easy-to-digest nutrients for the weak or injured.

examples: Example: Fat Layer - A layer of rendered fat will form on top as it cools. Skim this off and save it for cooking (ID 297).
Example: Seasoning - Add a pinch of wood ash (natural salt substitute) or wild herbs (thyme, oregano) if available.
dos: Crush the bones to increase surface area.
Simmer for as long as possible (24 hours is ideal).
Use joints and feet, not just the large spine bones.
donts: Don't boil too vigorously (it emulsifies the fat).
Don't consume the bones themselves.
Don't use bones from a suspected sick animal.

survivalGuides.title: Sautéed Insects (Grasshoppers, Crickets, Ants)
survivalGuides.description: High-protein survival food preparation. Focus on common, non-stinging insects and the necessary steps to make them safe and palatable.
quickSteps: 1. Collect non-stinging, non-brightly colored insects.
2. Chill or drown them to dispatch humanely.
3. Remove wings, legs, and heads (optional).
4. Sauté them on a flat, hot rock or pan for 5–10 minutes.

fullSteps.detail: Focus on grasshoppers, crickets, or termites. To clean, place them in a bag/jar overnight; they will expel waste. The next morning, dispatch them.
Pinch off the wings and large, spiny jumping legs (grasshoppers) as these are difficult to digest. Cooking will kill most parasites and neutralize defensive chemicals.
Use rendered fat (if available) or sauté them dry on a hot surface. Cook until they are crunchy and dried out (like popcorn). The crunch is crucial for safety and digestion.
Eat the cooked insects immediately. They can be crushed into a meal and added to broth or flour patties to boost protein content.

examples: Example: Ants - The abdomen of large ants can be crushed and added to broth for a tangy, acidic flavor (formic acid).
Example: Grubs - Larvae (grubs) should be skewered and roasted until the outer skin is crisp (ID 287).
dos: Cook all insects thoroughly.
Avoid fuzzy or brightly colored insects (high toxin risk).
Harvest after the first frost to avoid possible parasitic worms.
donts: Don't eat spiders, scorpions, or centipedes.
Don't eat insects that sting, bite, or smell bitter.
Don't rely on insects as your only food source.

survivalGuides.title: Pine Needle Tea (The Vitamin C Booster)
survivalGuides.description: A simple tea from Pine needles, which is an excellent source of Vitamin C (anti-scurvy) and hydration.
quickSteps: 1. Harvest fresh, green needles from a **Pine**, **Spruce**, or **Fir** tree.
2. Cut the needles into small pieces (increases surface area).
3. Bring clean water to a boil.
4. Remove the water from the fire and steep the needles for 5–10 minutes.

fullSteps.detail: **Crucially**, only use needles from true Pine, Spruce, or Fir trees. **AVOID YEW AND PONDEROSA PINE**, which are toxic. Look for needles that come in bundles of 2-5 or are attached individually.
Collect fresh, green needles (avoid brown, dry ones). Rinse them in clean water and chop them finely with a knife or rock.
Boil water first, then remove it from the direct heat source. Add the chopped needles and let them steep. **Do not boil the needles**, as high heat destroys Vitamin C.
Pour the tea through a strainer (cloth or mesh) to remove the needles. Drink warm. Flavor can be slightly bitter/piney.

examples: Example: Flavoring - Add a touch of natural sweetener like Maple sap (ID 270) or a few available berries for flavor.
Example: Storage - Tea must be drunk immediately; do not store the steeped tea for more than a few hours.
dos: Steep the needles in *removed* boiling water (not boiling them directly).
Use fresh, vibrant green needles.
Double-check tree identification.
donts: Don't use needles from Yew or Ponderosa Pine (poisonous).
Don't boil the needles.
Don't over-steep (it increases bitterness).

survivalGuides.title: Wild Greens Pottage (Dandelion/Clover)
survivalGuides.description: A simple, boiled mixture of commonly found edible wild greens, roots, and water, designed to maximize vitamin and mineral intake.
quickSteps: 1. Identify 3-4 edible wild greens (e.g., Dandelion, Clover, Chickweed).
2. Wash the greens thoroughly in clean water.
3. Chop the greens and roots (if used) finely.
4. Boil in clean water for 15 minutes; eat the greens and the nutrient-rich water.

fullSteps.detail: Harvest young, tender leaves (older leaves are often bitter). Wash them thoroughly to remove dirt and insects. If possible, boil them in one batch of water and discard the water to remove bitterness, then transfer to a second batch for the final meal.
If available, add chopped Cattail root (starch) or a handful of cracked nuts/acorn meal (ID 282) to make the meal more caloric and filling.
Boil in a small amount of water to create a thick pottage. If bones are available, use bone broth (ID 283) as the liquid base for maximum benefit.
The resulting pottage is a dense, soft meal. It is an excellent vehicle for getting vitamins, minerals, and hydration when in poor health.

examples: Example: Bitterness - Boiling bitter greens (like mature Dandelion leaves) twice drastically improves flavor.
Example: Seasoning - Wild onion, garlic mustard, or garlic grass can be added for flavor.
dos: Cook all greens and roots to ensure safety and digestibility.
Focus on young growth (less bitter).
Harvest away from roadsides and urban runoff.
donts: Don't eat white clover flowers raw (mildly toxic).
Don't consume any greens you have not positively identified.
Don't eat large quantities of greens without some caloric base.

survivalGuides.title: Roasted Grubs and Larvae Skewers
survivalGuides.description: A preparation method for high-fat, high-protein larvae (wood borers, beetle grubs) found in rotting logs, making them safe and palatable.
quickSteps: 1. Collect pale, soft-bodied grubs from rotting wood.
2. Clean them briefly in water.
3. Skewer 5-10 grubs on a thin stick.
4. Roast them over coals until the outer skin is crisp and golden.

fullSteps.detail: Use an axe, knife, or digging stick to break apart soft, rotting logs or stumps. Look for the large, white, C-shaped grubs. Avoid brightly colored or hairy varieties.
Gently rinse the grubs. They should be skewered using a thin, green wooden stick or long thorn. Skewering prevents them from curling up and burning.
Hold the skewer over hot coals (not flame). Roast slowly, rotating constantly, until the outer skin is crisp and dry, and the inside is cooked through. They will darken slightly.
Eat them immediately. They have a rich, fatty, nutty flavor. Grubs are one of the most calorically dense survival foods.

examples: Example: Tree Termites - These can be eaten raw, but taste better when briefly roasted or toasted in a dry pan.
Example: Dispatch - Placing the grubs in a hot pan briefly will dispatch them and make them easier to skewer.
dos: Cook all grubs thoroughly to kill parasites.
Focus on pale, white, non-hairy larvae.
Harvest them fresh; they spoil quickly.
donts: Don't eat larvae from poisonous plants (e.g., Monarch caterpillars).
Don't eat grubs that are dark or smell strongly of ammonia.
Don't eat them raw (high parasite risk).

survivalGuides.title: Simple Survival Hardtack (Flour/Water Only)
survivalGuides.description: A very basic, long-storage cracker made from any available survival flour (acorn, grass seed, pine bark) and water, cooked until rock-hard.
quickSteps: 1. Mix survival flour (ID 282) with clean water to form a stiff dough.
2. Flatten and cut the dough into 2-inch squares (1/2 inch thick).
3. Poke holes (fork/stick) completely through the biscuits.
4. Bake or dry-fry until completely hard (remove all moisture).

fullSteps.detail: Combine the flour with just enough water to create a very stiff, non-sticky dough. Knead briefly. The dough must be dry to prevent rapid spoilage.

Roll or press the dough into a thick sheet (1/2 inch). Cut into squares. Use a stick, nail, or fork to pierce holes (docking) completely through the dough. This allows moisture to escape during baking.
Bake on a flat rock or piece of metal over low coals for 30–60 minutes, flipping often. The goal is to dry the cracker out completely, not to bake it like bread. It should be brittle.
Hardtack can last years if fully dried. It is too hard to chew and must be soaked in water, broth (ID 283), or tea before consumption.

examples: Example: Consumption - Soak the hardtack in your mouth for 5 minutes before trying to chew it.
Example: Improvised Pan - A flat, thick piece of shale or granite can serve as a baking surface if wiped clean.
dos: Bake until completely moisture-free.
Ensure the flour is fully dry before mixing.
Store in a dry, sealed container.
donts: Don't skip the docking (poking holes).
Don't use raw, unprocessed flour (must be safe for consumption).
Don't add fat (it reduces shelf life).

survivalGuides.title: Clay-Sealed Whole Fish Bake (Self-Steaming)
survivalGuides.description: A primitive, hands-off cooking method using a thick clay or mud shell to steam and bake a whole fish directly in hot coals. The scales/skin peel off with the clay.
quickSteps: 1. Do not scale or gut the fish.
2. Completely cover the whole fish in a 1-inch thick layer of wet clay/mud.
3. Place the clay ball directly in hot coals (not flame).
4. When the clay is rock-hard and dry, crack it open to reveal the cooked fish.

fullSteps.detail: If possible, remove the gills and internal organs (gutting) through a small slice, but **do not remove the scales**. The scales and skin provide a protective layer.
Coat the entire fish (head to tail) in a layer of wet, pliable clay or mud at least 1 inch thick. Ensure there are no cracks or air holes. This seals in all the moisture.
Place the clay-wrapped fish directly into a bed of hot, white/red coals (not fire). Cover the ball completely with the coals and hot ash.

Cooking time varies (20–60 minutes) based on size. The clay should be totally dry and hard. Crack the clay shell with a stick or rock. The scales, skin, and sometimes the bones, will stick to the clay, leaving tender meat.

examples: Example: Bird/Game - Small birds (with feathers) or small game (with skin) can be cooked this way; the feathers/skin will peel off with the mud.
Example: Seasoning - Wild herbs (e.g., mint) can be placed inside the cavity of the fish before sealing the clay.
dos: Use thick, wet clay/mud.
Ensure the shell is completely crack-free.
Use hot coals, not high flame.
donts: Don't cook directly in flame (it burns the clay and meat).
Don't use sand (it doesn't seal well).
Don't rush the cooling process (can dry out the meat).

survivalGuides.title: Stone-Boiled Wild Stew (No Pot Required)
survivalGuides.description: A method to boil water and cook a mixed stew of meat/plants using hot rocks dropped into a non-metallic, watertight container (e.g., bark, hide, woven basket).
quickSteps: 1. Find non-porous river rocks.
2. Build a watertight container (bark sheet/lined hole).
3. Place meat, plants, and water in the container.
4. Heat rocks until red-hot, then drop them carefully into the water.

fullSteps.detail: Select smooth, non-porous river stones. Avoid granite, shale, or porous stones, which can explode due to trapped water. Heat the rocks in a fire until they are white or red-hot.
Create a vessel from a large piece of bark (folded and secured), a woven basket lined with clay, or a stomach/hide from a harvested animal. Fill it with water and ingredients (meat, roots, greens).

Use green sticks to retrieve the hot rocks. Wipe off any ash, then gently drop the hot rocks into the water. The water will boil almost instantly. Use a fresh rock every 2-3 minutes to maintain the boil.
Continue adding rocks until the water has been vigorously boiling for 15–30 minutes, ensuring the meat and roots are fully cooked and safe for consumption.

examples: Example: Container Lining - If using a wooden bowl, line the bowl with aluminum foil (if available) or wet clay to prevent it from burning.
Example: Water Quality - The boiling process purifies the water while cooking the food.
dos: Always use clean, dry sticks to handle the hot rocks.
Use non-porous river rocks.
Keep the rocks submerged until they cool.
donts: Don't touch the hot rocks with bare hands.
Don't use rocks with cracks or trapped moisture (explosion risk).
Don't use salt water (it doesn't boil as efficiently).

survivalGuides.title: Pine Cambium Flour/Mush (The Inner Bark)
survivalGuides.description: Harvesting the thin, white, starchy inner bark layer (cambium) of pine or birch trees to be eaten raw, dried, or ground into a caloric flour substitute.
quickSteps: 1. Identify a healthy Pine, Spruce, or Fir tree.
2. Make a shallow horizontal cut and a vertical cut (rectangle) on the trunk.
3. Gently peel back the rough outer bark.
4. Scrape off the moist, white layer (cambium) and consume or dry it.

fullSteps.detail: Use a knife to cut a small rectangle into the tree's outer bark, then carefully pry it off. The cambium is the thin, white, moist layer between the rough outer bark and the hard wood.
Scrape the cambium off the trunk or the back of the peeled bark in thin strips. This layer is starchy and can be eaten immediately (raw) or dried for later use.
If storing, dry the strips in the sun or near a low fire until brittle. Grind the brittle strips into a fine powder (flour). This flour can be mixed into hardtack (ID 288) or broth.
Never girdle (cut all the way around) a tree. Only harvest a small section to allow the tree to survive and heal the wound.

examples: Example: Consumption - The fresh strips can be eaten raw; they have a sweet, piney taste. Boiling them makes them soft like noodles.
