2. Place the oldest items at the front of the shelf (First Out).
3. Move newer, longer-dated items to the back (Last In).
4. Integrate your stored food into your regular, daily diet to ensure constant turnover.

fullSteps.detail: Create a simple inventory list of stored food. Label each shelf/storage bin with the earliest expiration date of the contents. Use a marker to write the date clearly on the top/front of the container.
Use tiered shelving or racks so items at the back are easily visible and accessible, but place the oldest items nearest the front access point.
Once a month, deliberately choose stored food for a regular meal. Replace the used items with fresh stock with the furthest-out expiration date. This keeps the supply in continuous rotation.
Keep a separate, sealed container of absolute emergency rations (MREs or high-calorie blocks) that are not part of the FIFO rotation. These are only for when all else is gone.

examples: Example: Canning - Label home-canned goods with the date of canning, not an expiration date, and prioritize them over commercially packaged foods.
Example: Bulk Goods - For items like rice/beans, store them in airtight containers (mylar bags, buckets) and label the date of bulk purchase/sealing.
dos: Cycle stock regularly into your daily diet.
Store food in airtight, rodent-proof containers.
Keep inventory organized by date.
donts: Don't buy new food and just place it on top of the old stock.
Don't store food near chemicals or extreme temperatures.
Don't rely on 'best by' dates (use your judgment for shelf-stable goods).

survivalGuides.title: Identifying Contamination Vectors (Pests/Air)
survivalGuides.description: Identifying and mitigating biological vectors (pests, animals) and environmental vectors (dust, airflow) that can carry pathogens into a secured shelter.
quickSteps: 1. Seal all structural gaps (cracks, vents, pipe openings) to block pests/air.
2. Set traps (snap/glue) for mice, rats, and insects (cockroaches/flies).
3. Monitor air intake: filter all incoming air (ID 334) if ventilation is required.
4. Regularly inspect and clean high-risk areas (food storage, waste disposal, ID 348).

fullSteps.detail: Walk the perimeter and plug all holes larger than 1/4 inch (mice can fit). Use steel wool, caulk, or plaster to seal gaps around utility lines, vents, and foundation cracks. This is essential for pest and airflow control.
Pests carry disease on their bodies and waste. Use simple snap traps for rodents. Keep all food storage locked and off the ground. Never leave standing water open (attracts mosquitoes).

If operating under forced ventilation, install a high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filter over the intake. If no filter is available, use multiple layers of dense cotton cloth (ID 334) as a temporary screen.
Maintain a strict distance from all wild animals (including pets that roam outside). Enforce the 'Hot Zone' protocol (ID 332) for all human entry/exit to control disease transfer.

examples: Example: Fly Traps - Hang strips of sticky paper or use a simple jar trap (sugar water) to control flying insects.
Example: Garbage - Store all refuse in a tightly sealed, dedicated bin outside the main living area (ID 348).
dos: Seal all holes and cracks in the shelter.
Keep food storage meticulously clean.
Filter/screen all incoming air.
donts: Don't use chemicals/poisons near food storage.
Don't rely on a loose screen for protection from insects.
Don't ignore the presence of even a single rodent.

survivalGuides.title: Lockdown Mental Health (Routine & Purpose)
survivalGuides.description: Strategies for maintaining psychological stability, cohesion, and morale during extended isolation periods by establishing structure, purpose, and communication.
quickSteps: 1. Establish a strict, daily schedule (wake time, meals, chores).
2. Assign specific, necessary roles/tasks to every group member (Guard, Cook, Medic).
3. Schedule dedicated time for physical exercise and intellectual activity (reading/games).
4. Maintain open, non-judgmental communication (daily status check/debrief).

fullSteps.detail: The loss of control causes anxiety. Counter this with an established, predictable daily routine. Assign specific meal times, chore blocks, and sleep times to create anchors in the day.
Every person must feel essential. Assigning roles (Water Manager, Security Watch, Inventory Specialist) validates their existence and prevents apathy and boredom. Rotate tasks to prevent burnout.

Schedule time for exercise (even simple calisthenics) and sun exposure (if safe). Encourage reading, journaling, or low-stakes creative projects to keep the mind engaged and prevent dwelling on the crisis.

Implement a neutral, no-blame system for resolving interpersonal conflicts. Hold a short, non-mandatory 'debrief' meeting at the end of the day where individuals can voice concerns or observations without immediate critique.

examples: Example: Education - Use stored books or teaching materials to establish a daily 'learning hour' for children and adults.
Example: Sleep Hygiene - Avoid napping during the day and ensure the sleeping area is cool, dark, and as quiet as possible (ID 340).
dos: Maintain a daily routine.
Assign meaningful roles to everyone.
Force time for exercise and sunlight.
donts: Don't allow individuals to isolate themselves completely.
Don't let chores pile up (leads to visual and moral decay).
Don't ignore signs of depression or severe anxiety.

survivalGuides.title: Improvised Noise Dampening (Doors/Floors)
survivalGuides.description: Techniques for eliminating common shelter noises (creaking doors, squeaky floors, rattling windows) to maintain silence, especially when under threat (zombies, hostile groups).
quickSteps: 1. For squeaky door hinges, use oil, lard (ID 297), or bar soap to lubricate the hinge pin.
2. For creaking floorboards, place a small amount of baby powder/talc in the crack and sweep it in.
3. Use rags, blankets, or cut foam strips to fill the gap/seal around all windows/door frames.
4. Tape down or remove all rattling hardware (chains, keys, loose metal). (ID 333).

fullSteps.detail: Squeaky floors are often caused by friction between wood. Sprinkle talcum powder, wood ash, or baking soda into the crack and use a brush to work it in. If possible, secure the board to the joist using long screws or small nails.

Apply lubricant (cooking oil, Vaseline, rendered fat) to the hinge pins. For the door latch, wrap a small rubber band or fabric strip around the handle/latch mechanism to prevent the bolt from clicking when the door is closed.
Use small, tightly rolled rags, paper, or foam strips and wedge them firmly into the space between the window pane and the frame. This stops the vibration caused by wind or nearby movement.
Identify the quietest, most stable pathways through the shelter and communicate these 'Quiet Routes' to all group members (ID 333). Never run inside.

examples: Example: Footsteps - Walk only on the joists (often where the floor meets the wall) or wear thick socks/moccasins to minimize impact noise.
Example: Metal - Use duct tape to cover all exterior metal surfaces that might clang (e.g., mailboxes, tool handles).
dos: Use oil or soap for hinges.
Use powder for floorboard cracks.
Tape down or remove all loose metal objects.
donts: Don't use water to lubricate metal (it rusts).
Don't attempt to move heavy furniture across a creaking floor.
Don't walk heavily or run inside the shelter.

survivalGuides.title: Water Barrel Purification (Long-Term Storage)
survivalGuides.description: Preparing and maintaining large-volume water storage (e.g., 55-gallon drums, cisterns) for long-term safety and consumption during a lockdown or quarantine.
quickSteps: 1. Use only food-grade, opaque (light-blocking) barrels or tanks.
2. Fill the tank with clean, filtered water (ID 302).
3. Add non-scented household bleach (sodium hypochlorite) at a rate of 1/4 teaspoon per gallon of water.
4. Seal the container completely and store in a cool, dark location.

fullSteps.detail: Thoroughly clean the container with soap and water, then rinse with a strong bleach solution (1 tablespoon of bleach per gallon of water). Rinse again with clean water.

Fill the barrel with water. Add the chlorine (bleach) at the correct ratio (1/4 teaspoon per gallon). Mix gently by rolling the barrel or stirring with a sanitized stick. This kills bacteria, viruses, and prevents algae growth.

Seal the lid tightly to prevent evaporation and contamination. Label the barrel with the date of storage and the amount of chlorine added. Store the barrels off the ground, in a cool, dark place (prevents plastic leaching and algae).
Stored water should be rotated/re-purified every 6–12 months. If the water has no faint chlorine smell, it needs to be re-treated. If cloudiness or particles are present, dump, clean, and start over.

examples: Example: Rainwater - If using rainwater, filter it through a cloth/charcoal (ID 302) before adding the chlorine.
Example: Retrieval - Use a small hand pump or spigot attached near the bottom for retrieval, minimizing contact with the stored water.
dos: Use only non-scented bleach.
Store barrels in a dark, cool environment.
Label with the date of treatment.
donts: Don't use barrels that previously held chemicals or oil.
Don't drink water that smells or tastes strongly of chlorine (it's over-treated).
Don't use flavored or 'splash-less' bleach.

survivalGuides.title: The 'Look-Away' Maneuver (Handling Strangers)
survivalGuides.description: A psychological tactic for moving through populated areas by signaling non-aggression, disinterest, and low-value status to avoid attracting hostile attention.
quickSteps: 1. Avoid all direct, prolonged eye contact (appears as a challenge or threat).
2. Maintain a slightly slumped, non-confrontational body posture (hands visible).
3. Walk with purpose but without looking around excessively (signals knowledge/preparedness).
4. Do not display high-value gear (weapons, shiny objects, large packs) in the open.

fullSteps.detail: Avoid wearing tactical gear or openly displaying weapons (ID 208) unless absolutely necessary. Carry a minimal-looking pack and wear neutral, dirty, or drab clothing. Look like a refugee or someone with little to offer.

Keep your head down slightly, as if focused on your immediate path or goal. Scan the periphery with your eyes only, not your whole head. A quick, downward glance (submissive) is safer than a challenging stare.
Walk at a steady, moderate pace. Moving too fast signals panic or a rush to a resource; moving too slowly signals weakness or loitering. Do not stop in sight of others unless necessary.
If engaged, keep answers brief, vague, and polite. Never volunteer information about your location, group size, or resources. Signal non-interest by ending the conversation quickly and moving on.

examples: Example: Gear Concealment - Wrap a quality backpack (ID 349) in a cheap, large trash bag to disguise its value.
Example: Dialogue - If asked where you are going, state a non-specific, distant location ('out west,' 'past the river') rather than your actual destination.
dos: Maintain non-confrontational posture.
Keep valuable gear hidden.
Walk with purpose and minimal fuss.
donts: Don't make direct, long eye contact.
Don't wear bright, clean, or new clothing.
Don't ever stop walking in front of a hostile group.

survivalGuides.title: Sanitizer Generation (Bleach/Alcohol Mix)
survivalGuides.description: Formulating effective, short-term sanitizing solutions (hand and surface) using common household chemicals (bleach or high-proof alcohol).
quickSteps: 1. **Bleach Solution (Surface):** Mix 5 tablespoons (1/3 cup) of unscented 5% bleach per gallon of water.
2. **Bleach Solution (Hand/Water):** Mix 1 teaspoon of unscented 5% bleach per gallon of water (for large-scale hand wash).
3. **Alcohol Solution (Hand):** Use high-proof alcohol (90% rubbing alcohol) straight or dilute to 60%+ with water/aloe.
4. **Crucially**, never mix bleach and ammonia or bleach and vinegar (toxic gas risk).

fullSteps.detail: Use only plain, unscented household bleach (sodium hypochlorite) that is less than one year old. Label the concentration clearly. **NEVER** mix with vinegar, ammonia, or other cleaners (releases deadly chlorine gas).
For cleaning countertops, tools, and the 'Hot Zone' (ID 332), use the stronger 5-tablespoon per gallon solution. Allow the solution to sit on the surface for 5 minutes before wiping.

Alcohol (ethanol/isopropyl) must be at least 60% concentration to be effective. If using 70% alcohol, use as-is. If using stronger alcohol, you may mix it with water or a mild thickener (Mallow root slime, ID 313) to prevent rapid evaporation.
Store bleach solutions in opaque containers (light breaks down the active chemical) and label them immediately. Alcohol should be stored in tightly sealed containers away from heat/flame.

examples: Example: Bleach Test - If the bleach solution smells strongly of chlorine after 5 minutes, it is too concentrated; dilute it.
Example: Tool Sanitizing - Tools used on a sick person or in a contaminated area should be soaked in the strong bleach solution for 10 minutes.
dos: Use unscented bleach only.
Store solutions in dark, labeled containers.
Maintain at least a 60% alcohol concentration.
donts: Don't mix bleach with other cleaners.
Don't use the surface solution on skin (it irritates/burns).
Don't use low-proof alcohol (below 60%).

survivalGuides.title: Creating a Pressure Alarm System (Tripwire)
survivalGuides.description: Building a perimeter early-warning system using simple, salvaged materials to alert the group to external movement or intrusion (hostiles, zombies, animals).
quickSteps: 1. Secure a very thin, dark line (fishing line, dental floss) 6 inches above the ground.
2. Tie one end of the line to a fixed point (tree, post).
3. Tie the other end to a noise-making device (cans, pot, bells, or rocks).
4. Set the 'alarm' mechanism in a concealed area where it will fall and make noise upon contact with the line.

fullSteps.detail: The tripwire should be thin, non-reflective (dark fishing line is ideal), and secured approximately ankle-high (6–8 inches). Place it at natural choke points or along the shelter perimeter (ID 335).

The alarm must be a loud, high-pitched noise. String multiple empty cans, small bells, or hang a metal pot so that a small stack of rocks is balanced on the lid. The tripwire's tension should hold the rocks in place until triggered.

Test the alarm to ensure it is loud enough to be heard from inside the shelter. Disguise the tripwire by placing it over natural-looking debris (leaves, branches) but ensure the line is not obstructed.
All group members must know the location of the tripwire to prevent false alarms. The sound of the alarm is the trigger for immediate silence and stationing at defensive positions (ID 335).

examples: Example: Directional Alarm - Set up different types of alarms (e.g., cans vs. bells) on different sides of the shelter to indicate the direction of the intrusion.
Example: Pressure Plate - A small board balanced on a rock can create a high-leverage pressure plate for heavier items/people.
dos: Use dark, thin, non-reflective line.
Set the alarm in a concealed spot.
Test the system for sensitivity and noise level.
donts: Don't use brightly colored twine or rope.
Don't place the alarm directly outside a sleeping area (causes panic).
Don't leave the tripwire active when moving in or out of the shelter.

survivalGuides.title: Suture and Wound Debridement (Self-Care)
survivalGuides.description: Essential steps for self-treating deep lacerations, focusing on cleaning (debridement) and closing the wound (suturing/stapling) to prevent severe infection or blood loss.
quickSteps: 1. Stop the bleeding with pressure (ID 188).
2. Clean the wound by removing all foreign matter (debridement) with sterilized tweezers/knife.
3. Irrigate the wound thoroughly with clean, sanitized water (ID 341).
4. Close the wound using sterilized sutures, staples, or adhesive strips (for shallow cuts) and dress tightly.

fullSteps.detail: Wash hands thoroughly. Sterilize all tools (needle, tweezers, thread/suture kit) by boiling or soaking in high-proof alcohol (ID 343). Administer pain reliever if available (ID 331).

Use sterilized tweezers/scalpel to cut away (debride) any dead, ragged, or contaminated tissue. This step is painful but critical. Remove all dirt, gravel, cloth fibers, or foreign matter, as they are sources of infection.

Flush the wound vigorously with clean, pressurized water (use a syringe or squirt bottle). Close the wound by either suturing (stitching) or using skin glue/staples. Only suture clean wounds; a potentially infected wound should be packed and left open.

Apply clean gauze and change the dressing daily. Monitor for signs of infection (redness, heat, swelling, pus, fever). If a deep wound becomes infected, remove the sutures/dressing to allow it to drain (ID 184).

examples: Example: Improvised Closure - Use strong adhesive tape (duct tape cut into strips) to pull the skin edges together for shallow cuts.
Example: Larvae - Maggots (if clean) can be used to debride a necrotic (dead) wound, but this is a last resort (ID 184).
dos: Thoroughly clean all debris from the wound.
Sterilize all tools before use.
Leave potentially infected wounds open to drain.
donts: Don't suture a wound that is actively draining pus.
Don't use unsterilized thread (use dental floss or fishing line if necessary).
Don't ignore signs of fever or spreading infection.

survivalGuides.title: Bartering Protocol (Valuables and Trust)
survivalGuides.description: Establishing rules for trade and exchange in a non-currency environment, identifying high-value goods, and minimizing the risk of betrayal.
quickSteps: 1. Identify the 'Top 5' universal commodities: Fuel, Ammo, Medical Supplies (ID 345), Tobacco/Alcohol, and Water (ID 341).
2. Never trade directly from your main stash (use a separate 'trade cache').
3. Always negotiate in a neutral location, with armed backup visible (ID 335).
4. Trade small, high-quality, pre-counted/measured quantities (e.g., 5 rounds of 9mm for 1 pound of sugar).

fullSteps.detail: Common, consumable goods become high-value: salt, sugar, yeast, coffee/tea, batteries, bleach (ID 343), and specialized tools. Avoid trading items that cannot be easily measured or divided.

The trade must occur in a secure, neutral location visible to your security team. Never allow the counter-party to know the location of your shelter or your full inventory. Maintain a firm, non-aggressive, but defensive posture.

Inspect all goods thoroughly. If trading medicine, verify expiration dates and check for signs of tampering. If trading seeds, ask for a sample to test (ID 314). Do not accept spoiled or clearly low-quality items.
Only trade with people you can verify or who belong to an established, reputable group. In a survival situation, never trade 'on credit.' The transaction must be completed on the spot.

examples: Example: Rarity - Items like sewing needles, quality thread, and writing implements can be disproportionately valuable.
Example: Information - Good intelligence (location of a resource, path around a threat) can be bartered for, but always verify it before acting.
dos: Trade only in neutral, controlled zones.
Trade small, measured quantities.
Use a security escort and cover.
donts: Don't trade essential supplies (only surplus).
Don't trade on credit or debt.
Don't reveal your primary shelter location.

survivalGuides.title: Securing Vertical Access (Ladders/Ropes)
survivalGuides.description: Controlling roof, attic, and upper-level access points in a lockdown scenario to prevent intrusion (hostiles, zombies that can climb) and maintain observation.
quickSteps: 1. Remove all external ladders and climbing aids (e.g., large bins, scaffolding).
2. Block/board up access to attic vents, skylights, and crawl spaces (ID 335).
3. Install a simple rope ladder (ID 176) for emergency access only.
4. Set up an observation post on the highest secured point (roof, second floor).

fullSteps.detail: Clear the shelter perimeter of anything that can be used to climb to the roof or upper floors (trash cans, large shrubs, stacked items). Store external ladders inside or conceal them far away.
Reinforce any hatch or scuttle on the roof. If using a permanent rope, pull it up when not in use. Use a simple knot (ID 151) or carabiner to secure the rope to an internal anchor.

Designate a high point (roof or highest floor window) as an OP. Keep silent movement (ID 333) and comms protocols (ID 336) strict at the OP, as this is the most visible location. Keep binoculars and a basic signaling kit ready.
Upper-floor windows should have anti-fall measures (ropes, harnesses) and be quickly removable for emergency evacuation/egress.

examples: Example: Roof Edge - Stringing a tripwire (ID 344) with cans or bells around the roof edge can serve as an early warning of vertical intrusion.
Example: Tree Removal - Cut down any tree limbs that offer bridge access to the shelter roof or upper floors.
dos: Remove all external climbing aids.
Reinforce all roof hatches/vents.
Use a simple, internal anchor for ropes.
donts: Don't leave ladders accessible to the public.
Don't use the same window for observation and ventilation.
Don't ignore basement/crawl space access (a low vertical threat).

survivalGuides.title: Waste Disposal and Odor Control (Containment)
survivalGuides.description: Managing human and biological waste in a sealed environment to prevent disease, control odor, and avoid attracting attention (pests, infected, hostiles).
quickSteps: 1. Use a dedicated 'sanitation bucket' system (sealed container/toilet lined with a bag).
2. Add quicklime, ash (ID 306), or small amounts of bleach (ID 343) after each use (odor/disease control).
3. Seal the bag tightly and remove it to a dedicated, secured 'waste cache' location far from the shelter.
4. Burn or bury all non-essential paper/refuse in a controlled fire (ID 346) when safe.

fullSteps.detail: Line a sturdy bucket with a heavy-duty trash bag. This is the sanitation system. After use, add a chemical agent (lime, chlorine bleach, or ash) to neutralize odor and pathogens. Securely seal the bucket lid.
Used bandages, contaminated cloth (ID 332), and sanitary napkins must be double-bagged and sealed separately. These are high-risk vectors.

Odors attract pests (ID 338) and animals. The sealed waste bags must be moved immediately to a concealed, off-site cache (pit, sealed vault, far from water sources). Never bury waste close to the shelter.
For general refuse (cans, plastic), crush them flat to save space. Wash and reuse items when possible. Burn flammable refuse only when the smoke plume will not draw unwanted attention.

examples: Example: Urine Diversion - Urine is sterile; it can be collected separately and used (if necessary) for flushing, cooling, or, in extreme cases, for fire starting (contains urea/salt).
Example: Diapers/Bandages - Soak heavily contaminated items briefly in a bleach solution before sealing and disposal.
dos: Use a chemical agent to treat all waste.
Seal and remove waste quickly and far from the shelter.
Crush all solid refuse to save space.
donts: Don't pour untreated human waste into water sources.
Don't burn refuse near the shelter (smoke plume).
Don't use the waste cache as a short-term solution.

survivalGuides.title: The Bug-Out Vehicle (BOV) Kit & Checklist
survivalGuides.description: Pre-packing and staging a vehicle with essential gear, tools, and supplies for rapid evacuation or long-distance travel to a secondary shelter location.
quickSteps: 1. Select a reliable, high-clearance vehicle; keep the fuel tank constantly topped up.
2. Stock the vehicle with a '3-day minimum' kit (water, food, first aid).
3. Include navigation tools, vehicle repair tools, and spare fluid/tires.
4. Place a secure, concealed water and fuel siphon in the kit.

fullSteps.detail: Maintain the vehicle rigorously (oil, tires, battery). Keep the fuel tank full (always above 3/4). Install a subtle engine kill-switch for security. Use a tire pressure gauge and keep all tires slightly over-inflated.

Kit must include at least 72 hours of water and shelf-stable food (MREs). Include heavy blankets/sleeping bags, shovel, and recovery gear (tow rope/chains). All items should be secured to prevent rattling (ID 333).
Include a quality First Aid/Trauma kit (ID 345), a tool kit (wrenches, duct tape, zip ties), and a fire extinguisher. Keep a secured weapon in a pre-defined, non-visible location inside the vehicle.
Pre-map at least three separate evacuation routes (primary, secondary, tertiary) using paper maps (no GPS reliance). Mark potential resource/fuel stops and known choke points.

examples: Example: Fuel Siphon - Keep 20 feet of clear tubing and a sealed canister of fuel stabilizer in the kit.
Example: Concealment - Use drab-colored material (tarps, blankets) to cover gear and windows when the vehicle is parked.
dos: Keep the fuel tank full at all times.
Include spare oil, fluids, and belts.
Secure all gear to prevent rattling.
donts: Don't rely solely on one route.
Don't store the BOV kit where it is visible to the public.
Don't rely on GPS/phone for navigation.

survivalGuides.title: Basic Fever/Symptom Isolation Protocol
survivalGuides.description: The immediate protocol for isolating a group member who develops fever, respiratory symptoms, or other signs of high-risk disease during a quarantine.
quickSteps: 1. Identify a dedicated isolation room/tent/section of the shelter.
2. Immediately move the symptomatic person (The Patient) to the isolation area.
3. Designate one healthy person (The Attendant) to care for The Patient.
4. All supplies, waste (ID 348), and clothes used in isolation must stay in the isolation area.

fullSteps.detail: The isolation area must be physically separate, have its own ventilation (if possible, separate from the main living area), and its own dedicated sanitation bucket (ID 348).

Only one person should be the primary caregiver (Attendant) to minimize exposure. The Attendant must wear a 3-layer mask (ID 334) and gloves whenever interacting with The Patient and must follow the decon protocol (ID 332) before returning to the main group.

No items (plates, cups, blankets) from the isolation area may return to the main living area without being thoroughly sterilized (boiling or strong bleach solution, ID 343). All liquid waste must be treated (ID 348).

The Patient may only rejoin the group after being symptom-free (no fever, no cough) for a pre-determined period (e.g., 48–72 hours). The entire isolation area and its contents must then be fully decontaminated.

examples: Example: Observation - Use a thermometer or touch test to monitor The Patient's temperature multiple times daily and record it.
Example: Comms - Use a radio or speaking tube for communication to avoid close-range contact while checking on The Patient.
dos: Isolate immediately upon first symptom.
Designate only one Attendant.
Sterilize or discard all isolation items after use.
donts: Don't allow the isolation person to wander or leave the area.
Don't share food or water containers with The Patient.
Don't allow The Attendant to skip the decon protocol.

survivalGuides.title: The 'Drop, Cover, and Hold On' Protocol
survivalGuides.description: The mandatory, immediate action sequence to protect oneself from falling and flying debris during an earthquake.
quickSteps: 1. **DROP:** Immediately fall to your hands and knees (prevents being thrown down).
2. **COVER:** Crawl under the nearest sturdy object (table, desk) to protect your head and neck.
3. **HOLD ON:** Grip your cover until the shaking stops, moving with it if necessary.
4. If no cover is available, drop next to an interior wall and protect your head/neck with your arms.

fullSteps.detail: As soon as shaking begins, drop to the ground. This prevents falls, which are a leading cause of injury during earthquakes.
Crawl quickly to a heavy, sturdy piece of furniture (desk, table). These items create a protective void space against falling ceilings and walls.
Grip the leg or edge of the cover with one hand. Use the other hand to cover your neck and head. Be prepared to shift your position if the cover moves.
If outdoors, move away from buildings, utility poles, and overhead wires. If driving, pull over safely, stop, and stay inside the vehicle.

examples: Example: Car - Pull over to a clear area, set the parking brake, and remain in the vehicle until the shaking stops.
Example: Tall Building - Drop, Cover, and Hold On; do NOT use elevators and do NOT rush for the stairs.
dos: Prioritize head and neck protection.
Stay put until the shaking stops.
Use the sturdiest furniture available.
donts: Don't run outside during the shaking.
Don't stand in doorways (they are often unstable).
Don't use elevators.

survivalGuides.title: The 'Triangle of Life' Debate (When to use)
survivalGuides.description: A controversial alternative to Drop, Cover, and Hold On—seeking shelter next to, rather than under, objects to create a survival void space.
quickSteps: 1. Identify large, crush-proof objects (refrigerators, washing machines, couches).
2. Drop next to the object, ensuring it is away from an outside wall.
3. Curl into a fetal position and cover your head/neck.
4. **Warning:** This method is only viable in structures prone to total pancake-style collapse (rare in modern buildings).

fullSteps.detail: The 'Triangle of Life' is most relevant in countries with poor building codes where heavy ceilings fall straight down (pancaking). In modern, framed structures, falling debris will strike the floor first.
Choose an object that is guaranteed not to crush (e.g., a steel file cabinet or heavy appliance). Never select an object that can easily topple over onto you (e.g., a tall bookcase).
Crawl to the side of the object in the fetal position. This minimizes your profile. The belief is that the object will create a triangular, debris-free void when the ceiling falls.
Official agencies overwhelmingly recommend the 'Drop, Cover, and Hold On' protocol (ID 351) as the safest method in almost all scenarios, prioritizing protection from small, flying debris.

examples: Example: Low Priority - Do not use this method in a light, wooden structure; the debris will fall laterally, not straight down.
Example: High Priority - Consider this only in basement areas or highly unstable, old stone/brick buildings.
dos: Use only against crush-proof objects.
Only consider in high-risk, non-modern structures.
Maintain a fetal position.
donts: Don't rely on this in a modern, framed building.
Don't stand near unstable furniture.
Don't use doorways.

survivalGuides.title: Post-Quake Utility Shut-off (Gas/Water/Electric)
survivalGuides.description: The immediate protocol after the shaking stops: shutting off critical utilities to prevent fire, explosion, flooding, and electric shock.
quickSteps: 1. **Gas:** Locate the main gas valve (usually outside) and use a wrench (ID 356) to turn it off completely.
2. **Electricity:** Turn off all breakers in the main electrical panel (the main switch first).
3. **Water:** Locate the main water shut-off valve and turn it off to conserve stored supply and prevent flooding.
4. Only turn utilities back on when certified professionals confirm safety.

fullSteps.detail: If you smell gas (sulfur/rotten eggs) or hear a hissing sound, evacuate immediately. If safe, use an adjustable wrench or specific gas shut-off tool (stored nearby) to turn the valve 90 degrees (perpendicular to the pipe). **Never** turn the gas back on yourself.
Locate the main breaker panel. Flip the main circuit breaker (usually a large one at the top) to the 'OFF' position. This prevents potential sparks from damaged wiring that could ignite gas leaks.
Shutting off the water main prevents water loss from damaged pipes, conserving any remaining water pressure for fire suppression and protecting your clean storage (ID 341).
Check for visible damage (cracked foundation, broken chimney). Do not re-enter damaged structures. Do not turn utilities back on until inspected and cleared by the utility company.

examples: Example: Tool Storage - Always keep a wrench (ID 356) taped or chained near the gas meter for immediate access.
Example: Water Source - Before shutting off the water, fill bathtubs and sinks if possible, as remaining water in pipes will drain quickly.
dos: Locate all shut-offs beforehand.
Use a wrench to turn off the gas.
Turn off the main electrical breaker first.
donts: Don't use lighters or matches to check for gas leaks.
Don't touch electrical switches or appliances if standing in water.
Don't turn the gas back on yourself.

survivalGuides.title: Assessing Structural Damage (The 7-Point Check)
survivalGuides.description: A rapid, safe protocol for determining if a building or shelter is safe to occupy or requires immediate evacuation.
quickSteps: 1. **Chimney:** Check for cracks/leaning (indicates roof damage).
2. **Foundation:** Look for large, deep cracks near the base (ID 335).
3. **Exterior Walls:** Check for visible bowing or separation from the roof.
4. **Floors:** Note any significant sloping or sinking.
5. **Interior Walls:** Look for large diagonal cracks above door/window frames.
6. **Plumbing:** Check for leaks, especially hot water tanks/septic systems.
7. **Odor:** Check for gas (ID 353) or sewage smells.

fullSteps.detail: Always assess the outside before attempting to re-enter. Look for damage to the chimney, which can fall later. Check the utility entrances (gas, electric) for separation.

Check the foundation for horizontal or diagonal cracks that are wide (1/4 inch or more). These indicate serious structural shifting. Check support posts/beams in basements/crawl spaces for snapping or crushing.
Inspect interior walls for 'X' or diagonal cracks—these indicate racking damage where the wall is trying to collapse sideways. If the ceiling or roof is visibly sagging, evacuate immediately.
Shut off utilities (ID 353) if not already done. Check the hot water heater and furnace/boiler for leaks or displacement. Water leaking from a ceiling is a sign of severe roof damage.

examples: Example: Small Cracks - Fine hairline cracks in plaster/drywall are often cosmetic and do not indicate structural failure.
Example: Re-Entry - If there is significant visible damage or the smell of gas, do NOT re-enter. Mark the building as unsafe.
dos: Check outside before going inside.
Prioritize foundation and chimney checks.
Look for wide, deep cracks.
donts: Don't assume the structure is safe after an initial glance.
Don't touch electrical systems if water is present.
Don't light candles or use open flames inside.

survivalGuides.title: Evacuation to a Designated Safe Zone
survivalGuides.description: Pre-planning a route and destination to a location known to be safe from immediate post-quake hazards (fires, landslides, aftershocks).
quickSteps: 1. Identify a large, open area (park, sports field) away from buildings, poles, and hillsides.
2. Pre-map the evacuation route (walking) avoiding overpasses, cliffs, and narrow streets.
3. Carry your Go-Bag/72-Hour kit (ID 349).
4. Move quickly but safely, using silent movement protocols (ID 333) if needed.

fullSteps.detail: The primary safe zone must be a wide, open area (a football field, a large town square). The distance from the nearest building should be at least the height of that building to protect against collapse or falling debris.

Your route should avoid bridges, tunnels, and areas prone to landslides or rock falls. If you are near the coast, your destination must be on high ground, at least 100 feet above sea level (Tsunami warning, ID 366).
Once at the safe zone, establish contact with group members (ID 336). Do not use phones unless necessary to keep lines clear for emergency responders.
Do not re-enter the home or main shelter until the area has been cleared by authorities, or you have confirmed structural safety (ID 354). Stay alert for aftershocks.

examples: Example: Safe Area - A parking lot surrounded by low-slung buildings is safer than a narrow street surrounded by high-rises.
Example: Group Gathering - Ensure all group members know a primary and secondary meeting spot at the safe zone.
dos: Move to an open area away from structures.
Carry your Go-Bag (ID 349).
Avoid overpasses and bridges.
donts: Don't stop near damaged buildings.
Don't rush back for non-essential items.
Don't use the car unless absolutely necessary (roads may be cracked).

survivalGuides.title: Improvised Debris Removal Tools (Prying/Lifting)
survivalGuides.description: Using salvaged materials to create levers, pry bars, and lifting aids for light search and rescue operations (e.g., clearing a path or freeing a trapped person).
quickSteps: 1. **Lever:** Find a long, straight, heavy piece of metal (rebar, fence post) or wood (2x4).
2. **Fulcrum:** Find a small, hard, crush-proof object (rock, brick, pipe) to act as the pivot point.
3. **Pry Bar:** Use the claw-end of a hammer, a heavy screwdriver, or a wrench (ID 353) to force open doors/windows.
4. Never attempt to lift heavy debris alone; always use a team and spotters.

fullSteps.detail: The longest possible lever provides the greatest mechanical advantage. Place the fulcrum (pivot point) close to the object you are lifting (the load) and push down on the opposite end (the effort). Secure the load immediately upon lifting (shores).

Shoring is crucial. As soon as a load is lifted, use short, sturdy blocks of wood, stacked bricks, or stable debris to fill the void. This prevents the load from falling back down and crushing the victim or the rescuer.
Use a flat piece of metal (e.g., a car jack handle, a thick butter knife) to pry apart jammed doors or windows. Never pry with a tool that could snap or shatter.
Always wear gloves (ID 364) and eye protection (goggles) when working with debris. Dust, glass, and sharp metal edges are high risks. Be aware of the building's stability (ID 354) before entering.

examples: Example: Jack - A vehicle jack (ID 349) is the ideal debris lifting tool for heavy rubble, but it is slow and must be used with shoring.
Example: Sledge - Use a heavy rock wrapped in cloth (to prevent slippage) as an improvised hammer or sledge to clear small rubble.
dos: Use the longest lever available.
Use a fulcrum close to the load.
Always shore a lifted object immediately.
donts: Don't use a rotten or cracked piece of wood as a lever.
Don't attempt to lift heavy concrete alone.
Don't enter a visibly unstable structure.

survivalGuides.title: Controlling Secondary Fires (Post-Quake)
survivalGuides.description: Immediate steps to extinguish small fires caused by gas/electrical leaks, which are common post-earthquake and can lead to massive conflagrations.
quickSteps: 1. **Gas & Electric:** Shut off all utilities immediately (ID 353).
2. **Small Fires:** Use a fire extinguisher (if available), water, or smother with dirt/sand/heavy blankets.
3. **Large Fires:** Evacuate immediately (ID 355) and do not attempt to fight them.
4. Treat burns immediately (ID 184) after extinguishing.

fullSteps.detail: If the fire is electrical, kill the power (ID 353). If it is a gas leak, kill the gas. A fire without fuel cannot grow.
If you have a Fire Extinguisher: **P**ull the pin, **A**im the nozzle at the base of the fire, **S**queeze the handle, and **S**weep the nozzle from side to side at the base.
For small kitchen fires, cover the fire with a heavy lid or use baking soda (if available). For outdoor fires, use shovels to throw dirt or sand onto the flames.
If a group member is burned, cool the burn immediately with running, clean water (ID 302). Do not apply ointments or oils. Cover the burn with a clean, sterile cloth (ID 345).

examples: Example: Chimney Fire - If your chimney has collapsed (ID 354), any existing fire can quickly spread to the attic; use water to douse the remnants of the firebox.
Example: Clothes - Stop, Drop, and Roll if clothing catches fire. Smother flames with a heavy blanket or sleeping bag.
dos: Shut off all utilities before fighting a fire.
Aim at the base of the fire.
Evacuate if the fire grows rapidly.
donts: Don't use water on electrical or grease fires.
Don't fight a fire that is taller than you or has spread beyond the point of origin.
Don't re-enter a burning building for any reason.

survivalGuides.title: Signaling for Help (Visual/Auditory)
survivalGuides.description: The protocol for signaling rescuers when trapped under rubble, using both noise and light to communicate location.
quickSteps: 1. **The 3s Rule:** Wait for a quiet moment, then signal 3 short bursts of noise (whistle, tapping, shouting).
2. **Auditory:** Use a whistle (stored in your Go-Bag, ID 349) or tap on pipes/concrete (metal carries sound farthest).
3. **Visual:** Use a mirror (ID 190) or flashlight (ID 331) to send an SOS signal (3 short, 3 long, 3 short) when light/rescuers are near.
4. **Conservation:** Do not shout continuously; conserve energy and voice for when rescuers are heard nearby.

fullSteps.detail: Shouting constantly wastes energy and reduces the chances of rescuers hearing you. The key is to wait for quiet periods and then signal the 3-burst call.
Tapping on metal (pipes, rebar, steel beams) transmits sound much farther than tapping on rubble or shouting. Use a rock or a hard object to strike a rhythm (3 taps, short pause, 3 taps, etc.).
A simple survival whistle can be heard from a greater distance than the human voice and requires less energy. Use 3 long blasts for the distress signal.
If light or an opening is available, use a mirror to flash sunlight or use a flashlight in the international SOS code (3 dots, 3 dashes, 3 dots).

examples: Example: Metal - Listen for tapping/shouting from other trapped people; tap back 3 times to let them know you are near.
Example: Timing - If you hear rescuers, wait for them to stop moving/talking, then use the 3s signal immediately.
dos: Conserve your voice and energy.
Use a whistle or metal tapping.
Wait for quiet periods to signal.
donts: Don't shout constantly.
Don't waste battery life on continuous light.
Don't accidentally signal if no one is near (wait for quiet periods).

survivalGuides.title: Sustaining in Rubble (Water and Dust)
survivalGuides.description: Immediate survival measures for a person trapped in a debris field, prioritizing water, air quality, and psychological control (ID 339).
quickSteps: 1. **Control Dust:** Cover your nose and mouth immediately with any available cloth (ID 334) to prevent inhaling dust.
2. **Water:** Locate any stored water (from your Go-Bag) or find any sealed containers in the rubble (juice boxes, cans).
3. **Minimize Movement:** Stay in the safest position you can find (Triangle of Life, ID 352) to prevent causing secondary collapse.
4. **Signal:** Conserve your energy for signaling (ID 358) during quiet periods.

fullSteps.detail: The most immediate risk is inhaling fine dust particles (concrete, asbestos, fiberglass), which can quickly damage the lungs. Use a cloth mask, shirt, or scarf to filter the air.
Ration any food or water found. Do not drink untreated water from broken pipes unless absolutely necessary (high risk of contamination). Avoid eating food exposed to dust/debris.
Maintain hope and a sense of time (ID 339). Mark the passing hours/days by tapping or using a small rock to tally time. Focus on the immediate task of survival: signaling and conserving energy.
Unless in immediate, life-threatening danger (fire, rising water), do not attempt to dig yourself out. You risk causing the rubble to shift and further crushing yourself or causing collapse.

examples: Example: Liquid - If you have a damp piece of cloth, suck the moisture from it rather than drinking questionable water.
Example: Signaling - Use a piece of broken glass or shiny plastic to flash light when you hear people nearby.
dos: Protect your lungs from dust.
Ration all food and water.
Maintain psychological control (ID 339).
donts: Don't panic and shout continuously.
Don't try to move heavy debris alone.
Don't drink water from broken pipes/sewer lines.

survivalGuides.title: Temporary Debris Triage (Marking Status)
survivalGuides.description: A system for marking damaged structures and victims to communicate immediate status to official rescue teams (FEMA/UN/Red Cross).
quickSteps: 1. **Structure Search:** Use a bright spray paint or chalk to mark the structure's status.
2. **The Box:** Draw a large box (X-Box) with the date/time of search (ID 354).
3. **Interior Quadrants:** Mark the number of living/dead found in the top/bottom sections of the box.
4. **Victim Triage:** Use the S.T.A.R.T. system (Immediate, Delayed, Minor, Deceased) to mark victims (ID 188).

fullSteps.detail: Use a clear, prominent mark (X or a large box) on the structure near the main entrance. Write the time and date of the search above the box. Write the search group's name/ID below the box.

Top Quadrant (Left): Mark the number of live victims found. Bottom Quadrant (Left): Mark the number of dead victims found. Right Quadrant: Mark potential hazards (Gas, Fire, Water). A diagonal line through the X means the structure is confirmed clear.

When aiding a victim, use colored cloth/tape to mark their status. Red (Immediate: severe breathing/bleeding), Yellow (Delayed: major fracture, stable), Green (Minor: walking wounded), Black (Deceased).
Use standard symbols (a single line for each count). If unable to count, mark 'potential victims' or 'unknown number.' The goal is quick, universally understood information.

examples: Example: Structure Mark - '1500 / 9-19' above the box, '3L / 1D' inside the top/bottom left quadrants, and 'GAS' in the hazard quadrant.
Example: Victim Mark - Tie a yellow piece of fabric (delayed) to the wrist of a victim with a broken leg and stable breathing.
dos: Use bright, visible markings (spray paint, chalk).
Date and time every mark.
Use the standard L/D (Live/Dead) format.
donts: Don't use pencil or non-permanent markers.
Don't enter and search alone.
Don't move critical victims until stabilized (ID 188).

survivalGuides.title: Emergency Lighting (Post-Quake Power Outage)
survivalGuides.description: Strategies for generating safe, immediate light after the power grid fails, avoiding open flames near gas leaks (ID 353).
quickSteps: 1. **Battery Power:** Use a headlamp or crank-powered flashlight (ID 331) immediately (safest).
2. **Chemical Light:** Break light sticks (chem lights) to provide low-level, continuous light (safe near gas).
3. **Cautions:** Do not light candles or use lighters until the absence of gas leaks is confirmed.
4. **Conservation:** Use red light mode (if available) to conserve night vision and battery life.

fullSteps.detail: Always use battery-powered flashlights or headlamps for the first few hours, especially if indoors, until the all-clear for gas leaks is given. Headlamps keep both hands free for debris clearance or first aid.
Light sticks provide 6–12 hours of low-level light that is safe to use anywhere, including near suspected gas leaks. Use them to mark safe pathways or the location of stored supplies.
If gas is confirmed off (ID 353) and no fumes are present, a candle (ID 246) can be safely used in a protective container (glass jar) away from flammable materials.
Conserve batteries by only using lights when necessary. If possible, use the lowest light setting. Store batteries separately from devices to prevent drainage.

examples: Example: Water Bottle Lamp - Tape a headlamp to the side of a clear water bottle (ID 341) to diffuse the light and create a wide-area lantern.
Example: Car Battery - A car battery can be safely wired to run a low-voltage light for several days.
dos: Use flashlights/headlamps immediately.
Confirm no gas leak before using open flame.
Use light sticks for long-term, safe area marking.
donts: Don't light candles immediately after a quake.
Don't use lighters for area inspection.
Don't waste light on non-essential tasks.

survivalGuides.title: Collecting Post-Quake Water (Hot Water Tank)
survivalGuides.description: A technique for accessing the stored, potable water inside a household hot water tank when the main water supply is compromised or shut off.
quickSteps: 1. Shut off the water supply valve leading into the hot water tank.
2. Shut off the gas/electric to the tank (ID 353).
3. Open a hot water faucet on a lower floor of the house (creates a vacuum/release).
4. Drain the tank from the spigot at the bottom into clean containers (ID 341).

fullSteps.detail: Turn off the cold water supply valve leading *into* the hot water tank. This prevents back-siphonage and potential contamination from the ground water supply if pipes are broken.
Open a hot water faucet (usually a tub or sink) on the lowest floor of the structure. This breaks the vacuum and allows the water to flow from the tank.

Attach a hose to the drain spigot at the bottom of the tank (or place a bucket directly under the spigot). Open the spigot and collect the water. A standard 40-gallon tank can provide a group with 4 days of water.

This water is generally potable but can contain rust/sediment. Filter it through a cloth (ID 302) before use. Check the exterior of the tank for cracks or damage (ID 354) before attempting the process.

examples: Example: Toilet Tank - The water in the top tank of a toilet (not the bowl) is potable and should be collected before the hot water tank, as it is easier to access.
Example: Boiling - If the water smells stale or has a noticeable taste, boil it (ID 302) before consumption.
dos: Shut off the water line into the tank first.
Open a low-level hot water faucet.
Filter the water before consumption.
donts: Don't drink water from the toilet bowl or radiator.
Don't assume the tank water is completely sterile.
Don't try to move a full hot water tank.

survivalGuides.title: Securing Stored Supplies (Seismic Restraint)
survivalGuides.description: Pre-positioning and securing heavy items and survival caches (ID 331) to prevent them from falling, breaking, or becoming inaccessible after a major quake.
quickSteps: 1. Move heavy items (bookshelves, refrigerators) away from beds/seating.
2. Anchor tall furniture (cabinets, shelves) to wall studs with heavy-duty straps/L-brackets.
3. Install a latch or bolt lock on all cabinet doors and drawers containing fragile/heavy items.
4. Store water and emergency food (ID 337) in low, stable locations (floor, under the bed).

fullSteps.detail: Use flexible straps or sturdy L-brackets (screwed into wall studs) to secure the top of all heavy, tall furniture. Flexible straps absorb movement better than rigid brackets.

Install a child-proof latch or hook-and-eye bolt on cabinet doors, especially those containing breakables (glass) or chemicals (bleach/cleaners, ID 343). This prevents them from flying open and spilling/shattering.
Survival supplies (Go-Bags, water barrels, canned goods) should be stored on the floor level or the lowest shelving tier. This prevents them from falling and becoming debris or crushing occupants.
Do not hang heavy pictures or mirrors over beds or couches. Move beds away from windows and heavy furniture. Store hazardous materials (paint, oil, chemicals) in a separate, secured container.

examples: Example: Hot Water Tank - The hot water tank (ID 362) should be strapped to the wall studs in two places (upper and lower third) to prevent it from toppling over.
Example: Kitchen - Use non-skid material (rubber mats) inside kitchen cabinets to prevent items from sliding out when the door is opened post-quake.
dos: Anchor all tall furniture to the wall.
Lock or latch all cabinet doors.
Store heavy supplies low and securely.
donts: Don't store heavy items on the top shelves.
Don't rely on thin wire or tape for anchoring.
Don't place beds near windows or heavy objects.

survivalGuides.title: Personal Protective Equipment (Improvised)
survivalGuides.description: Using common items to protect the body against post-quake hazards (broken glass, debris, dust, contamination) during search/rescue (ID 356).
quickSteps: 1. **Hands:** Use heavy leather work gloves (must be in your kit, ID 331) or wrap hands/feet in heavy cloth/towels.
2. **Eyes:** Use sunglasses, swimming goggles, or plastic sheeting/tape for eye protection.
3. **Airway:** Use a cloth mask or bandana (ID 334) to protect against dust.
4. **Feet:** Wear hard-soled shoes (boots/sneakers) and tape broken shoes with duct tape (ID 356).

fullSteps.detail: Broken glass, nails, and sharp debris are the biggest immediate foot hazard. Never walk barefoot. Wear hard-soled boots or sturdy sneakers. If you must use flip-flops, wrap them tightly with duct tape to secure them to your ankle.

Gloves are mandatory for debris clearing. If no work gloves are available, wrap a thick towel, socks, or heavy cloth around your hands and secure them with tape or rope (ID 176). The key is puncture and laceration resistance.

Dust and fine particles are harmful to the eyes. Any form of eye coverage (ski goggles, lab glasses, sunglasses) is better than nothing. If unavailable, use a wide-brimmed hat to shade your eyes from direct overhead debris.
A bicycle helmet, motorcycle helmet, or construction hard hat is the ideal protection against small falling debris. If no helmet is available, use a thick hood or layer a towel over your head.

examples: Example: Improvised Goggles - Cut the front out of a plastic bottle and tape it securely over your eyes and nose.
Example: Leg Protection - Wrap thick jeans or towels around your shins and ankles (high risk areas) with duct tape.
dos: Wear hard-soled shoes at all times.
Protect hands with heavy material or gloves.
Cover your mouth and nose from dust.
donts: Don't walk barefoot indoors or outdoors.
Don't use thin leather gloves for debris removal.
Don't use safety pins or staples near eyes.

survivalGuides.title: Clearing the Debris Path (One-Way Lane)
survivalGuides.description: Creating a safe, stable pathway through a debris field to allow egress, transport of victims, and movement of rescue equipment.
quickSteps: 1. Designate a clear, single path (avoiding high-risk areas, ID 354).
2. Move all debris to one side of the path (the 'waste side').
3. Stabilize the pathway with flat boards or solid material (shoring, ID 356).
4. Mark the path clearly with light sticks or chalk (ID 361).

fullSteps.detail: Choose the most direct path that avoids large, unstable piles of debris or areas of known structural damage. The path should be wide enough for two people to pass (for victim transport).
Move all small and medium debris (glass, books, light rubble) to one side of the designated path. The waste side should act as a small stabilizing barrier if possible.
Use solid material (plywood, planks, pieces of dry wall) to create a stable, flat surface to walk on, preventing ankle and foot injuries (ID 364). Fill deep voids with compacted, stable rubble.
Mark the edges of the path clearly with reflective tape, chalk, or light sticks (ID 361) for low-light movement. Communicate the path to all group members and enforce a 'stay on path' rule.

examples: Example: Victim Transport - When moving a victim, use a large blanket or tarp as a drag sled to pull them along the cleared path, saving energy (ID 356).
Example: Clearing - A shovel or a piece of solid cardboard can be used as an improvised rake/pusher to move light debris.
dos: Create a stable, flat surface to walk on.
Move all debris to one side of the path.
Mark the path clearly.
donts: Don't move critical debris without shoring and a team.
Don't walk on a visibly unstable pile of rubble.
Don't allow the path to become cluttered again.

survivalGuides.title: Tsunami Evasion (Coastal Quake Protocol)
survivalGuides.description: The crucial protocol for coastal areas: any earthquake that lasts for more than 20 seconds is a natural tsunami warning; immediate evacuation is mandatory.
quickSteps: 1. If you feel strong shaking for 20+ seconds, do NOT wait for an official warning.
2. Immediately move inland and uphill (ID 355) on foot.
3. Seek refuge at least 100 feet (30 meters) above sea level AND 1 mile inland.
4. Do NOT go to the shore to watch; do NOT return after the first wave (multiple waves follow).

fullSteps.detail: A significant earthquake (one that you cannot stand through, or one lasting over 20 seconds) in a coastal region is the primary warning sign. The second sign is rapidly receding ocean water (the drawdown).

Do not drive; traffic will be jammed, and roads may be damaged. Evacuate immediately on foot to the nearest high ground. The safe zone should be at least 100 feet above sea level and as far inland as possible.

Tsunamis arrive as a series of waves (a bore), not a single one. The first wave may not be the largest. Do not return to the shore until all official warnings have been canceled (often many hours later).
If you cannot reach high ground, climb to the highest, strongest floor or roof of a reinforced concrete building. Stay away from the ocean-facing side. This is a last resort.

examples: Example: Height - Memorize the height of local buildings; if you must climb, choose a tall, modern structure that appears structurally sound (ID 354).
Example: Boat - If on a boat at sea, move the boat far offshore (deeper than 100 fathoms) where the wave is less dangerous.
dos: Move inland and uphill immediately.
Evacuate on foot, not by car.
Stay high until the all-clear is given.
donts: Don't wait for an official warning if you feel strong shaking.
Don't go to the shore to watch the ocean drawdown.
Don't return after the first wave.

survivalGuides.title: Basic First Aid (Treating Crush Injuries)
survivalGuides.description: Managing injuries caused by crushing forces (trapped limbs) to stabilize the victim and prevent secondary complications like Crush Syndrome.
quickSteps: 1. **Stabilize:** Do NOT immediately remove the crushing object; stabilize the debris/victim (ID 356).
2. **Bandage:** Control external bleeding and treat other injuries (ID 188).
3. **Hydration:** If conscious and debris is to be removed, begin forcing water/electrolytes (ID 341) into the victim *before* removal.
4. **Monitor:** Monitor for signs of shock (rapid heart rate, shallow breathing) and treat immediately (ID 188).

fullSteps.detail: A limb trapped for a long time accumulates toxins (Crush Syndrome). Releasing the pressure allows these toxins to flood the bloodstream, causing sudden cardiac arrest. **Only remove the object if absolutely necessary or if EMS is present.**

If the crushing object must be moved (e.g., life-threatening heat/fire), immediately begin hydrating the victim with water or electrolyte solution (if available). This dilutes the toxins before they can enter circulation.
Once the object is removed, immediately begin CPR if necessary (ID 188). Maintain hydration and keep the victim warm (ID 179) and still. The injured limb should be kept immobilized.
Crush injuries often cause internal damage not visible externally. Treat all crush victims as serious trauma patients, even if they appear conscious and stable.

examples: Example: Amputation - In extreme, life-or-death situations, if a limb is clearly severed and holding the person, it must be removed. This is a final, highly risky choice (ID 345).
Example: Monitoring - Watch for dark urine and swelling after removal; this is a sign of severe kidney damage from toxins.
dos: Stabilize the object and the victim first.
Hydrate the victim before removal (if forced to move the debris).
Treat all crush injuries as severe trauma.
donts: Don't remove the crushing object immediately without preparation.
Don't move the victim unnecessarily.
Don't assume the victim is fine just because they are talking.

survivalGuides.title: Food Protection (Pantry and Fridge Lock)
survivalGuides.description: Securing food sources against contamination and inaccessibility by anchoring refrigerators/freezers and securing pantry items (ID 363).
quickSteps: 1. Secure refrigerators/freezers to the wall studs with straps (ID 363) to prevent toppling.
2. Latch or lock the refrigerator/freezer door to prevent food from spilling/spoiling.
3. Store heavy items (canned goods) on the floor or bottom shelves of the pantry.
4. Follow the '4-hour rule' for refrigerated food once power is lost (ID 353).

fullSteps.detail: A toppled refrigerator/freezer can crush a person (ID 352) and causes immediate food loss. Use heavy-duty nylon straps or steel brackets to secure the unit to the wall.
Install a simple bolt or hook-and-eye latch to keep the refrigerator door securely closed during shaking, preventing food from falling onto the floor and getting contaminated.
Canned goods become projectiles. Store all heavy and sharp-edged items on the lowest shelves. Use small tension bars or strips of wood to prevent shelf contents from sliding forward and falling out.

If the power is out, keep the refrigerator and freezer doors closed. A full, closed freezer can keep food frozen for 48 hours. The fridge is only good for 4 hours. Discard anything with an unusual odor or texture.

examples: Example: Freezer - Use dry ice (if stored) to extend the freezer life. Move all refrigerated food into the freezer to maximize space and cold retention.
Example: Canned Goods - After the quake, inspect all canned goods for severe dents, swelling, or leaks; these may indicate botulism contamination.
dos: Anchor heavy appliances to the wall studs.
Latch the refrigerator door.
Keep the doors closed once power is out.
donts: Don't rely on adhesive for anchoring heavy appliances.
Don't eat spoiled or suspect food (ID 337).
Don't store heavy items on high, open shelving.

survivalGuides.title: Shelter-in-Place (When to Stay Inside)
survivalGuides.description: Determining when the shelter-in-place strategy (ID 335) is safer than evacuation (ID 355), primarily after a minor or moderate earthquake.
quickSteps: 1. The structure must be confirmed safe (ID 354) and clear of gas/electrical hazards (ID 353).
2. The external environment (streets, neighborhood) must be more dangerous than the interior.
3. You must have adequate supplies (ID 331) to last 72 hours minimum.
4. You must have a way to monitor the external situation (radio/scanner, ID 336).

fullSteps.detail: If the building survives the quake with minimal visible damage and all utilities are safely shut off, staying inside is often the safest option, as the risk of aftershocks is high, and the exterior environment is cluttered with debris.
If the outside risk is severe (e.g., mass looting, uncontained fires, major building collapse, high tsunami risk, ID 366), sheltering in a reinforced, secured location is paramount.
If sheltering in place, immediately initiate home fortification (ID 335). Barricade doors, cover windows, and restrict movement to a single, secure room. Maintain silent comms protocols (ID 333).
Keep Go-Bags near an accessible exit (not the main entrance). Even if sheltering in place, be ready for immediate evacuation should the situation (fire, structural failure) change.

examples: Example: Minor Quake - If the shaking is minor and you can confirm structural integrity (ID 354), stay inside to avoid falling debris on the streets.
Example: Major Quake - If the quake is severe and buildings around you have collapsed, evacuate immediately (ID 355) to an open area.
dos: Only stay if the structure is confirmed safe.
Barricade and secure the structure immediately (ID 335).
Keep Go-Bags ready for rapid egress.
donts: Don't stay if there is a known gas leak.
Don't shelter if you are on the coast (Tsunami risk, ID 366).
Don't leave windows and doors unsecured.

survivalGuides.title: Handling Aftershocks (Re-Initiating DCH)
survivalGuides.description: The protocol for responding to aftershocks—which can cause more damage than the main quake to already weakened structures—after the initial shaking has subsided.
quickSteps: 1. **Anticipate:** Aftershocks are highly likely and can last for days/weeks.
2. **Re-Initiate:** At the first sign of shaking, immediately perform Drop, Cover, and Hold On (DCH, ID 351).
3. **Damage Check:** After the aftershock, quickly re-check structural integrity (ID 354) and utility shut-offs (ID 353).
4. **Patience:** Only proceed with rescue/evacuation plans during confirmed periods of calm.

fullSteps.detail: Assume an aftershock is imminent for the first 72 hours. Do not let your guard down. When in the shelter, stay near sturdy furniture or interior walls.

fullSteps.step: Step 2: DCH in an Unsafe Structure
fullSteps.detail: If you are sheltering in a structure that you suspect is damaged (ID 354), immediately evacuate to the safe zone (ID 355) when the aftershock ends, as the movement likely worsened the structural instability.
Aftershocks can cause new gas lines or electrical systems to break. Be alert for new smells (gas/sewage) or signs of fire (ID 357).
Aftershocks increase stress (ID 339). Use the moments of calm to reassure group members and maintain the illusion of control (ID 339) by following the established routine/protocol.

examples: Example: Timing - The largest aftershock usually occurs within a few hours of the main quake, but smaller ones can occur for months.
Example: Debris Movement - A previously stable pile of debris (ID 356) can become unstable during an aftershock; keep a distance from them.
dos: Perform DCH (ID 351) immediately when shaking starts.
Anticipate aftershocks for days/weeks.
Re-check damage and utilities after each one.
donts: Don't assume the shaking is over after the first aftershock.
Don't relax your guard for 72 hours.
Don't try to continue tasks during the shaking.
